[[File:Corporation Street bollards.jpg|thumb|right|190px|HVM bollards enforcing a vehicle control zone in Manchester's pedestrianised city centre.]] '''Hostile vehicle mitigation (HVM)''' is a generic term that covers a suite of anti-terrorist protective measures that are often employed around buildings or publicly accessible spaces/venues of particular significance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hostile vehicle mitigation {{!}} Public Website|url=https://www.cpni.gov.uk/hostile-vehicle-mitigation|website=www.cpni.gov.uk|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Reference Manual to Mitigate Potential Terrorist Attacks Against Buildings|url=https://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/20130726-1455-20490-6222/fema426.pdf|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> The design of these various vehicle security barriers and landscape treatments came about as security authorities across the globe sought to mitigate the effects of [[Car bomb|vehicle borne improvised explosive devices]] (VBIED).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cormie|first1=edited by David|last2=Mays|first2=Geoff|last3=Smith|first3=Peter|title=Blast effects on buildings|date=2009|publisher=Thomas Telford Ltd|location=London|isbn=978-0-7277-3521-8|pages=250–273|edition=2nd|url=http://www.frontierpitts.com/fileadmin/user_upload/downloads/cpni/blast_effects_on_buildings_2nd_ed_chapter_11.pdf|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> The sorts of places that warrant consideration as potential terrorist targets in need of HVM include: government buildings, airports, large railway stations, sports venues, concentrations of entertainment and crowded night time economy, etc.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crowded Places Guidance|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/619411/170614_crowded-places-guidance_v1.pdf|publisher=NaCTSO|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Aston|first1=Heath|title=Terror guidelines urge blast mitigation measures for busy public areas|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/terror-guidelines-urge-blast-mitigation-measures-for-busy-public-areas-20160413-go58l5.html|accessdate=3 July 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=13 April 2016}}</ref>
Common types of HVM include locally manufactured barrier systems such as the [[Jersey barrier|Jersey Barrier]] and [[Bremer wall|Bremer T Wall]]; as well as propriety crash-tested and engineered vehicle bollard systems designed to resist the effects of a [[Vehicle-ramming attack|vehicle ram attack]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=TAL|first1=1/11|title=Vehicle security barriers within the streetscape (TAL 01/11) - GOV.UK|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/vehicle-security-barriers-within-the-streetscape|website=www.gov.uk|publisher=UK Government|accessdate=28 September 2017|language=en}}</ref> HVM can also include adapted hard landscape features, resistive street furniture, sculpture, planters and significant level changes; with a little imagination HVM may be disguised inside architectural features in a street scene.<ref>{{cite web|title=Integrated Security - a Public Realm Design Guide for Hostile Vehicle Mitigation - Second Edition|url=https://www.cpni.gov.uk/system/files/documents/40/20/Integrated%20Security%20Guide.pdf|website=CPNI|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McPhee|first1=Rod|title=Latest weapon against terrorism appearing all over UK but you won't have noticed|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/latest-weapon-against-terrorism-been-10088354|accessdate=3 July 2017|work=UK Daily Mirror|publisher=Mirror Newspapers|date=24 March 2017}}</ref>
HVM when installed and fixed correctly is designed to resist hostile vehicle penetration of certain categories of vehicle moving at a range of speeds,<ref>{{cite web|title=Guide to Active Vehicle Barrier (AVB) Specification and Selection Resources|url=https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/Guide-to-Active-Vehicle-Barrier-2014-508.pdf|publisher=US Government|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> these vehicle security barriers undergo various destructive tests carried out be accredited test establishments.<ref>{{cite web|last1=DfT|first1=CPNI|title=Traffic Advisory Leaflet 1/11|url=http://tsrgd.co.uk/pdf/tal/2011/tal-1-11.pdf|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hostile vehicle attacks - how do we make places safer? - Foundations|url=https://blog.esi.info/2017/06/20/hostile-vehicle-attacks-make-places-safer/|website=Foundations|accessdate=3 July 2017|date=20 June 2017}}</ref> The three standards that are generally quoted when specifying HVM performance are:
*[[ISO]] IWA 14-1 - an international working agreement<ref>{{cite web|title=IWA 14-1:2013 - Vehicle security barriers -- Part 1: Performance requirement, vehicle impact test method and performance rating|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/64736.html|website=www.iso.org|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en}}</ref> *[[BSI Group|BSI]] [[Publicly Available Specification|PAS]] 68 - the UK standard<ref>{{cite web|title=PAS 68:2013 - Impact test specifications for vehicle security barrier systems|url=http://shop.bsigroup.com/ProductDetail/?pid=000000000030273707|website=shop.bsigroup.com|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> *[[ASTM International|ASTM]] F2656-07 - the US standard.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASTM F2656 / F2656M - 15 Standard Test Method for Crash Testing of Vehicle Security Barriers|url=https://www.astm.org/Standards/F2656.htm|website=www.astm.org|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref>
These standards set roughly similar criteria for destructive impact testing, although there are differences between the three and vehicle geometries in particular are at the root of some of these differences. HVM barrier selection will be conditioned by a hostile [[vehicle dynamics]] study carried out by a suitably qualified security specialist.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Section|first1=9|title=Recognising the terrorist threat - GOV.UK|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/recognising-the-terrorist-threat/recognising-the-terrorist-threat|website=www.gov.uk|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:Dusk at Terminal 3 - geograph.org.uk - 610450.jpg|thumb|left|Concrete blocks placed to protect the Terminal 3 at [[Manchester Airport]] from hostile vehicle attack, these have now been replaced by more attractive bollards]][[Image:national.security.parliament.arp.750pix.Clean.jpg|thumb|Security measures taken to protect the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]. This hostile vehicle mitigation is a common form of target hardening and is designed to prevent a vehicle being rammed into the building or into people on the pavement next to the building. It also enforces a zone of protective stand-off from any explosive detonation location]]
Ideally a protective layer of HVM should surround the building or place being protected and this HVM protection line should be stood off from the building facade or places expected to be crowded. This protective standoff distance is critical in the case of VBIEDs as 'every metre counts' and often distance is one of the best ways to achieve explosive blast effects mitigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=IMPROVISED EXPLOSIVE DEVICE (IED) GUIDELINES FOR PLACES OF MASS GATHERING|url=https://www.nationalsecurity.gov.au/Media-and-publications/Publications/Documents/IED-Guidelines/IED-guidelines-places-mass-gathering.pdf|publisher=ANZCTC|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=FEMA 426, Chapter 4|url=https://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/20130726-1455-20490-7465/fema426_ch4.pdf|publisher=US Government|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> [[File:Southbridgearsenal.jpg|thumb|left|The ARSENAL lettering in the foreground of the Emirates Stadium is an example of disguised HVM]]
More recently the focus of HVM has expanded to reduce the potential for vehicle ram attacks directed at crowded events and places.<ref>{{cite web|title=Protecting Crowded Places: Design and Technical Issues|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/97992/design-tech-issues.pdf|publisher=HM Government|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> Recent non-VBIED (i.e. vehicle as a weapon) attacks against pedestrians include:
* The [[2016 Nice attack]] * The [[Ohio State University attack|2016 Ohio State University attack]] * The [[2016 Berlin attack]] * The [[2017 Jerusalem truck attack|2017 Jerusalem attack]] * The [[January 2017 Melbourne car attack]] * The [[Sandy, Utah attack|2017 Sandy, Utah attack]] * The [[2017 Stockholm attack]] * The [[2017 Westminster attack]] * The [[June 2017 London Bridge attack|2017 London Bridge attack]] * The [[2017 Finsbury Park attack]]
HVM can also be used to protect against [[Ram-raiding|ram raids]] which are invariably criminal attacks against high net-worth targets such as jewelers, [[Cash-in-transit|cash and valuables in transit]] depots, [[bullion]] storage facilities, art galleries, museums, 'high end' fashion stores, etc.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Louks|first1=Dominic|title=S10 - Guidance for protection of premises against vehicle attack (ram raid)|url=http://www.riscauthority.co.uk/free-document-library/RISCAuthority-Library_detail.s10-guidance-for-protection-of-premises-against-vehicle-attack-ram-raid.html|website=www.riscauthority.co.uk|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Correctly installed HVM barrier systems should not adversely affect pedestrian permeability.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bollards and Pedestrian Movement, TAL 2/13|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/565603/tal-2-13-bollards-pedestrian-movement.pdf|publisher=HM Government|accessdate=4 July 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[:Category:Deaths by car bomb|Deaths by car bomb]] * [[Improvised explosive device]] (IED) * [[List of mass car bombings]] * [[Vehicle-ramming attack]] * [[Counter-terrorism]] * [[Security]] * [[Physical security]]

4.[[Sheikh]] [[Farris Mana'a]] was a government ally until his arrest in 2010, after which he endorsed the Houthis and was appointed to head their administration. |casus= }} {{Campaignbox Insurgencies in Yemen}} {{Campaignbox Sa'dah insurgency}} {{Campaignbox Yemeni Crisis}} {{Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)}} The '''Houthi insurgency in Yemen''',{{cite news|first= Ginny|last=Hill|title= Yemen fears return of insurgency|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6331149.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2007-02-05|accessdate=2008-05-23}}{{cite journal|last=McGregor|first=Andrew|date=August 12, 2004|title= Shi'ite Insurgency in Yemen: Iranian Intervention or Mountain Revolt?|journal=Terrorism Monitor|volume= 2|issue=16|pages=4–6|publisher=[[The Jamestown Foundation]]|url=http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/ter_002_016.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-05-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061121131603/http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/ter_002_016.pdf |archivedate=November 21, 2006}} also known as the '''Houthi rebellion''', '''Sa'dah War''', or '''Sa'dah conflict''', was a [[rebellion|military rebellion]] pitting [[Zaidiyyah|Zaidi]] [[Shia Islam|Shia]] [[Houthis]] (though the movement also includes [[Sunni Islam|Sunnis]]https://globalvoices.org/2015/04/01/debunking-media-myths-about-the-houthis-in-war-torn-yemen/) against the [[Military of Yemen|Yemeni military]] that began in [[Northern Yemen]] and has since escalated into a [[Yemeni civil war (2015–present)|full-scale civil war]]. The conflict was sparked in 2004 by the government's attempt to arrest [[Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi]], a Zaidi religious leader of the [[Houthis]] and a former parliamentarian on whose head the government had placed a $55,000 bounty. Initially, most of the fighting took place in [[Sa'dah Governorate]] in northwestern Yemen, but some of the fighting spread to neighbouring governorates [[Hajjah Governorate|Hajjah]], [['Amran Governorate|'Amran]], [[Al Jawf Governorate|al-Jawf]] and the Saudi [[Jizan Region|province of Jizan]]. Since 2014 the nature of the insurgency has changed with the [[Houthi takeover in Yemen]] and then into the ongoing [[Yemeni civil war (2015–present)]] with a major [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|Saudi-led intervention in Yemen]] beginning in 2015.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8413450.stm|title=Crises multiply for divided Yemen|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=17 October 2014}} General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]] commanded the Yemeni security forces during the conflict and led all the government offensives from 2004 until 2011, when he resigned his post to defend protesters during the [[Yemeni Revolution]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/05/20115228013977326.html|title=The crucible of Yemen|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=22 May 2011|accessdate=17 October 2014}} A Houthi [[2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état|power grab]] in [[Sana'a]] escalated on 20 January 2015, when the rebels attacked the president's residence and swept into the presidential palace. President [[Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi]] was inside the residence as it came under "heavy shelling" for half an hour, but he was unharmed and protected by guards, according to Information Minister [[Nadia Al-Sakkaf]]. Presidential guards surrendered the residence after being assured that Hadi could safely evacuate. The [[United Nations Security Council|U.N. Security Council]] called an emergency meeting about the unfolding events. United Nations Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon|Ban Ki Moon]] expressed concern over the "deteriorating situation" in Yemen and urged all sides to cease hostilities.{{cite news|title=Rebels capture Yemen presidential palace, shell residence|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/01/20/yemen-shiite-rebels/22038397/|accessdate=20 January 2015|date=20 January 2015|newspaper=USA today}}{{cite news|title=Yemen rebels overtake presidential palace|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/1/20/yemen-crisis-negotiations.html|accessdate=20 January 2015|date=20 January 2015|newspaper=Al Jazeera}} On 22 January, President [[Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi]] and Prime Minister [[Khaled Bahah]] tendered their resignations to parliament, which reportedly refused to accept them.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30936940|agency=BBC|title=Yemen crisis: President resigns as rebels tighten hold|date=January 22, 2015|accessdate=January 22, 2015}} ==Background== {{One source|section|date=May 2015}} In 1962, a [[Yemen Arab Republic|revolution]] in [[Upper Yemen|North Yemen]] ended over 1,000 years of rule by [[Zaidiyyah|Zaidi]] [[Imams of Yemen|Imams]], who claimed descent from the [[Prophets in Islam|Islamic prophet]] [[Muhammad]]. [[Sa'dah]], in the north, was their main stronghold and since their fall from power the region was largely ignored economically and remains underdeveloped. The Yemeni government has little authority in Sa'dah.{{cite news| title=Profile: Yemen's Houthi fighters| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/08/200981294214604934.html|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]| date=2009-07-12| accessdate=2009-12-22}} During Yemen's [[1994 civil war in Yemen|1994 civil war]], the [[Wahhabi movement|Wahhabis]], an Islamic group adhering to a strict version of [[Sunni Islam]] found in neighboring Saudi Arabia, helped the government in its fight against the [[Democratic Republic of Yemen|secessionist south]]. Zaidis complain the government has subsequently allowed the Wahhabis too strong a voice in Yemen. Saudi Arabia, for its part, worries that strife instigated by the Zaidi sect so close to Yemen's border with Saudi Arabia could stir up groups in Saudi Arabia itself. The conflict was sparked in 2004 by the government's attempt to arrest [[Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi]], a Zaidi religious leader of the [[Houthis]] and a former parliamentarian on whose head the government had placed a $55,000 bounty. [[Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi]] movement accused [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] of massive financial corruption and criticized him for being backed by Saudi Arabia and United States{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/markaz/2017/12/18/who-are-the-houthis-and-why-are-we-at-war-with-them/|title=Who are the Houthis, and why are we at war with them?|last=Riedel|first=Bruce|date=2017-12-18|work=[[Brookings Institution]]|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US|author-link=Bruce Riedel}} at the expense of the Yemeni people{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3643600.stm|title=Yemeni forces kill rebel cleric|date=10 September 2004|newspaper=BBC News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061121091116/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3643600.stm|archivedate=21 November 2006|deadurl=no}} and Yemen's sovereignty.{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/briefly/2015/02/12/5-things-houthis-yemen/|title=5 Things to Know About the Houthis of Yemen|last=Streuly|first=Dick|date=2015-02-12|website=WSJ|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-04}} ==Motives and objectives== When armed conflict for the first time erupted in 2004 between the Yemeni government and Houthis, the [[Ali Abdullah Saleh|then Yemeni president]] accused Houthis and other Islamic opposition parties of trying to overthrow the government and the republican system. The Yemeni government alleged that the Houthis were seeking to overthrow it and to implement Zaidi [[religious law]]. Houthi leaders for their part rejected the accusation by saying that they had never rejected the president or the republican system but were only defending themselves against government attacks on their community. The Houthis said that they were "defending their community against discrimination" and government aggression.{{cite news|title=Deadly blast strikes Yemen mosque|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7379929.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2008-05-02|accessdate=2008-05-23}} The Yemeni government has accused [[Iran]] of directing and financing the insurgency.{{cite journal|last=Johnsen|first=Gregory D.|date=February 20, 2007|title=Yemen Accuses Iran of Meddling in its Internal Affairs|journal=Terrorism Focus|volume=4|issue=2|pages=3–4|url=http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/tf_004_002.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070616045131/http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/tf_004_002.pdf |archivedate=June 16, 2007}} According to a February 2015 ''[[Newsweek]]'' report, Houthis are fighting "for things that all Yemenis crave: government accountability, the end to corruption, regular utilities, fair fuel prices, job opportunities for ordinary Yemenis and the end of Western influence."{{cite news|title=Photo Essay: The Rise of the Houthis|url=http://www.newsweek.com/photo-essay-rise-houthis-305511|newspaper=[[Newsweek]]|date=9 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015}} In an interview with the ''[[Yemen Times]]'', Hussein Al-Bukhari, a Houthi insider, said that the Houthis' preferred political system is a republic with elections where women can also hold political positions, and that they do not seek to form a cleric-led government after the model of the [[Politics of Iran|Islamic Republic of Iran]] for "we cannot apply this system in Yemen because the followers of the [[Shafi]] doctrine are bigger in number than the Zaydis."{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1826/intreview/4467/Al-Bukhaiti-to-the-Yemen-Times-"The-Houthis'-takeover-can-not-be-called-an-invasion".htm|title=Al-Bukhari to the Yemen Times: "The Houthis' takeover can not be called an invasion"|newspaper=[[Yemen Times]]|date=21 October 2014|access-date=17 February 2015}} ==Timeline== {{further|Timeline of the Yemeni conflict (2011–present)}} ===Phase 1: June–September 2004=== From June to August 2004, government troops battled supporters of al-Houthi in the north.{{cite news| title=Clashes 'leave 118 dead' in Yemen| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3863463.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]| date=2004-07-03| accessdate=2007-02-03}} Estimates of the dead range from 500 to 1,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.ploughshares.ca/libraries/ACRText/ACR-Yemen.htm#Status |title=Armed Conflicts Report - Yemen |publisher=Ploughshares.ca |accessdate=2009-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030054141/http://www.ploughshares.ca/libraries/ACRText/ACR-Yemen.htm |archivedate=2009-10-30 |df= }} On 10 September, Yemeni forces killed al-Houthi.{{cite news| title=Yemeni forces kill rebel cleric| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3643600.stm| publisher=[[BBC News]]| date=2004-09-10| accessdate=2007-01-30}} Since then, the rebellion has been led by one of his brothers, [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]],{{cite news|first=Nasser |last=Arrabyee |title=Rebellion continues |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/743/re10.htm |work=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] |date=2005-05-25 |accessdate=2007-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619181842/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2005/743/re10.htm |archivedate=2007-06-19 |df= }} while his father, Badr Eddin al-Houthi, became the group's spiritual leader.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/shabab-al-moumineen.htm|title=al-Shabab al-Mum'en / Shabab al-Moumineen (Believing Youth) |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org|accessdate=29 December 2009}} ===Phase 2: March–June 2005=== Between March and April 2005, some 1,500 people were killed in a resurgence of fighting between government forces and supporters of the slain cleric, now calling themselves Houthis. In May 2005, the rebels rejected an offer of a [[presidential pardon]] by President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] after their conditions for surrender were refused by the government and minor clashes continued. On May 21, the government released estimates of the impact of the insurgency, announcing that it was responsible for 552 deaths, 2,708 injures, and over [[US$]] 270 million in economic damages. On 23 June 2005, the Houthis' military commander [[Abdullah al-Ruzami]] surrendered to Yemeni authorities after tribal mediators worked out a deal with the government. ===Phase 3: November 2005 – 2006=== Fighting broke out in November 2005 and continued until early 2006. The pro-government Hamdan tribe, led by Sheikh Abdullah al-Awjari, battled with pro-Houthi tribes and Houthis tried to assassinate a Ministry of Justice official in [[Dhamar, Yemen|Dhamar]] {{Citation needed|reason=missing source|date=December 2017}}. The fighting ended before the Presidential elections that year{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pUq4Wo1zSt0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Yemen+on+the+Brink&hl=en&ei=TbuMTvHzI6ek0QWS-PjSBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|author1=Christopher Boucek |author2=Marina Ottaway |title=Yemen on the Brink|publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|year=2010|accessdate=17 October 2014}} and in March 2006, the Yemeni government freed more than 600 captured Shī'a fighters. {{cite news| title=Yemen tells Shi'ite rebels to disband or face war| url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/world/20070129-0318-yemen-houthi-.html| publisher=Reuters| date=2004-01-29| accessdate=2007-01-30| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206035250/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/world/20070129-0318-yemen-houthi-.html| archivedate=2007-02-06| df=}} There was no data with regards to casualties in 2006, but they were said to be significantly lower than those of the previous year. ===Phase 4: January–June 2007=== Fighting broke out on 28 January 2007, when militants attacked a number of government installations, killing six soldiers and injuring 20 more.{{cite news| title='Shia gunmen' kill Yemeni troops| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6307703.stm| publisher=[[BBC News]]| date=2004-01-28| accessdate=2007-01-30}}{{cite news| first=Khaled| last=Al-Mahdi| title=95 Killed in Yemen Clashes| url=http://arabnews.com/?page=4§ion=0&article=92163&d=15&m=2&y=2007&pix=world.jpg&category=World| publisher=[[ArabNews]]| date=2007-02-15| accessdate=2007-04-11 }} Further attacks on 31 January left six more soldiers dead and 10 wounded.{{cite news| title=Shi'ite rebels kill six Yemen soldiers - Web site| url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L0118141.htm| publisher=Reuters| date=2007-02-01| accessdate=2007-02-03}} A further ten soldiers died and 20 were wounded in an attack on an army roadblock near the Saudi Arabian border on 1 February.{{cite news| title=Yemeni soldiers killed in attack| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/24D55138-C57E-455A-93D3-7B29E3D21C93.htm| publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]| date=2007-02-01| accessdate=2007-02-02}} Though there was no official confirmation of militant casualties in the attacks, government sources claim three rebel fighters were killed in a security operation following the 31 January attacks.{{cite news| title=10 soldiers killed in attack in Yemen| url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=19396| publisher=Middle East Online| date=2007-02-02| accessdate=2007-02-03}} In February, the government launched a major offensive against the rebels involving 30,000 troops.{{cite news|first=Nasser |last=Arrabyee |title=Yemen's rebels undefeated |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/838/re8.htm |publisher=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] |date=2007-04-04 |accessdate=2007-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416192857/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/838/re8.htm |archivedate=2007-04-16 |df= }} By 19 February, almost 200 members of the security forces and over 100 rebels had died in the fighting.{{cite news| title=More than 100 killed in 5 days of clashes between army and Shiite rebels clashes in Yemen, officials say| url=http://iht.com/articles/ap/2007/02/19/africa/ME-GEN-Yemen-Rebels.php| work=International Herald Tribune| date=2007-02-19| accessdate=2007-04-11}} A further 160 rebels were killed in the subsequent two weeks.{{cite news| title=160 rebels killed in Yemen| url=http://story.israelherald.com/index.php/ct/9/cid/940f2bfd509e743b/id/232503/cs/1/| work=Israel Herald| date=2007-03-07| accessdate=2007-04-11| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928035910/http://story.israelherald.com/index.php/ct/9/cid/940f2bfd509e743b/id/232503/cs/1/| archivedate=2007-09-28| df=}} A French student was also killed.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL26448929|title=Two killed in Yemen attack including a Frenchman|date=26 March 2007|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 December 2009}} A ceasefire agreement was reached on 16 June 2007. The rebel leaders agreed to lay down arms and go into exile in [[Qatar]] (by whom the agreement had been mediated), while the government agreed to release rebel prisoners, help pay for reconstruction and assist with [[Internally displaced person|IDPs]] returning home.{{cite news| first=Ahmed| last=Al-Hajj| title=Yemen's government, Shiite rebels negotiate end to 3-year conflict| url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2003751155_yemen17.html| work=[[The Seattle Times]]| date=2007-06-17| accessdate=2007-06-17| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620190558/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2003751155_yemen17.html| archivedate=2007-06-20| df=}} In total some 1,500 people were killed by the conflict in 2007, including 800 government troops, 600 rebels and 100 civilians. ===Phase 5: March–July 2008=== Armed incidents resumed in April 2008, when seven Yemeni soldiers died in a rebel ambush on 29 April.{{cite news| author=[[Reuters]]| title=Dozens of casualties in Yemen mosque blast| url=http://www.france24.com/en/20080502-dozens-casualties-yemen-mosque-blast&navi=MONDE| work=[[France 24]]| date=2008-05-02| accessdate=2008-05-23| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618085342/http://www.france24.com/en/20080502-dozens-casualties-yemen-mosque-blast%26navi%3DMONDE| archivedate=2009-06-18| df=}} On 2 May, 15 worshippers were killed and 55 wounded in a [[2008 Bin Salman Mosque bombing|bombing]] at the [[Bin Salman Mosque]] in [[Sa'dah]] as crowds of people left [[Friday prayer]]s. The government blamed the rebels for the bombing, but the Houthis denied responsibility.{{cite news| title=Deaths in Yemeni mosque blast| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/9B661165-2CD6-4582-8B4D-507C3653F795.htm| publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]| date=2008-05-02| accessdate=2008-05-23 }} Shortly after the attack, three soldiers and four rebels died in overnight skirmishes.{{cite news| agency=Associated Press| title=7 die as Yemeni troops, rebels clash after mosque attack| url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1209626997129&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull| work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]| date=2008-05-03| accessdate=2008-05-23| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713122956/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1209626997129&pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull| archivedate=2011-07-13| df=}} On 12 May, clashes between Yemeni soldiers and rebels near the border with Saudi Arabia killed 13 soldiers and 26 rebels.{{cite news| agency=Associated Press| title=Heavy clashes break out between Yemeni soldiers and Shiite rebels in nor| url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/05/12/africa/ME-GEN-Yemen-Clashes.php| work =[[International Herald Tribune]]| date =2008-05-12| accessdate=2008-05-23}} During fighting in May 2008, a total of 1,000 government forces were killed and 3,000 injured. Some 70,000 people were displaced by the fighting. President Saleh declared an end to fighting in the northern Sa'dah governorate on 17 July 2008.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/10/21/yemen20035.htm |title=Yemen: Hundreds Unlawfully Arrested in Rebel Conflict |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=2008-10-24 |accessdate=2009-11-09}} ===Phase 6: Operation Scorched Earth, August 2009 – February 2010=== {{Main|Operation Scorched Earth}} On 11 August 2009, the government promised to use an "iron fist" against the rebels. The Yemeni troops, backed by tanks and fighter aircraft, launched a fresh offensive, code-named Operation Scorched Earth,{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/10/2009102103834822778.html |title=Yemen denies warplane shot down |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2009-10-02 |accessdate=2009-11-09}} against the Houthis in the northern Sa'ada province. Hundreds of thousands of people were displaced by the fighting. On 17 September, more than 80 people were killed in an air raid on a camp for displaced people in northern Yemen.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8260414.stm |title='Many killed' in Yemen air raid |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-09-17 |accessdate=2009-11-09}} The conflict took on an international dimension late in the month. Clashes were reported between the Houthis and Saudi security forces near the border.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8341875.stm |title=Yemen rebels 'seize Saudi area' |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-11-04 |accessdate=2009-11-09}} Also, Yemeni officials captured a boat in the Red Sea that was transporting anti-tank shells and, according to some reports, five Iranian "instructors" sent to help the Houthis.{{cite news |title=Yemenis intercept 'Iranian ship' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8327892.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-10-27 |accessdate=2009-11-02}} Various official Iranian sources responded, calling this claim a politically motivated fabrication, and stating that the ship was traveling for business activities carrying no consignment.{{cite news |title=Iran says documents prove Yemen ship had no arms |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=109878§ionid=351020101 |publisher=Press TV |date=2009-10-28 |accessdate=2009-11-02}} In early November the rebels stated that Saudi Arabia was permitting Yemeni army units to launch attacks from across the border at a base in Jabal al-Dukhan, charges which were denied by the Yemeni government.{{cite news|title=Yemen rebels accuse Saudi |url=http://www.france24.com/en/node/4915529 |publisher=France 24 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2009-11-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711024909/http://www.france24.com/en/node/4915529 |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }} In late October, heavy clashes in the area of Razih led to the Houthis capturing two military headquarters and killing Yemeni General Amr Ali Mousa Al-Uuzali.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=109606§ionid=351020206 |title=Houthis kill top Yemeni commander |publisher=Presstv.com |date=2009-10-25 |accessdate=2009-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112625/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=109606§ionid=351020206 |archive-date=2011-07-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In early November, General Ali Salem al-Ameri and regional security chief [[Ahmed Bawazeir]] were killed in a Houthi ambush as they were returning from Saudi Arabia. === Attacking Saudi Arabian Borders, 4 November 2009 === The conflict took on an international dimension on 4 November 2009 when the Houthis attacked the Saudi border, killed one of the Saudi border guards, seized Al Khubah Village and other villages. The Houthis accuse [[Saudi Arabia]] of supporting the Yemeni government in attacks against them. It was not clear what type of support they meant. The Saudi government denied this.{{cite news| title=Timeline: Yemen| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/country_profiles/1706450.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]| date=2009-11-11| accessdate=2009-12-22}} The rebels shot dead a Saudi security officer in a cross-border attack. The rebels took control of a mountainous section inside Saudi Arabia, in the border region of [[Jabal al-Dukhan]] and occupied two villages inside Saudi territory.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=114578§ionid=351020206|title=Riyadh continues air raids on northern Yemen |date=24 December 2009|publisher=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.naharnet.com/domino/tn/newsdesk.nsf/MiddleEast/C8C778064ACBD59EC2257695003F6795?OpenDocument|title=Houthis Say they Will Withdraw from Saudi if Riyadh Ends Attacks|date=23 December 2009|publisher=Naharnet ([[Agence France-Presse|AFP]])|accessdate=29 December 2009}} The houthis had entered Saudi territory and attacked patrols, and that a second soldier later died from wounds sustained in the same clash.{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_air_force_hits_Yemen_rebels_after_border_raid.html?siteSect=143&sid=11454037&ty=ti |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120911203244/http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/international/Saudi_air_force_hits_Yemen_rebels_after_border_raid.html?siteSect=143&sid=11454037&ty=ti |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-11 |title=Saudi air force hits Yemen rebels after border raid |publisher=Swissinfo.ch |date=2009-11-05 |accessdate=2009-11-09 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6903635.ece |accessdate=November 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629113705/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6903635.ece |archivedate=June 29, 2011 |title=Yemen civil war spills over border as Saudi official is killed in attack|first1=James|last1=Hilder }} On 5 November, Saudi Arabia responded by launching heavy air strikes on rebels in northern Yemen, and moved troops nearer the border. Saudi government officials said only that the air force had bombed Yemeni rebels who had seized a border area inside the kingdom, which they said had now been recaptured. The officials said at least 40 rebels had been killed in the fighting. The Saudi government adviser said no decision had yet been taken to send troops across the border, but made clear Riyadh was no longer prepared to tolerate the Yemeni rebels. The Saudi assault continued the following day, as Saudi residents near the southern border of [[Jizan Province]] were evacuated.{{cite news |title=Saudi forces keep up Houthi assault |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/11/2009116125810626250.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=2009-11-06 |accessdate=2009-11-06}} At the same time, a Houthi spokesman reported to the media that they had captured Saudi troops.{{cite news |title=Yemeni rebels say capture Saudi soldiers: report |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE5A53G820091106 |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-11-06 |accessdate=2009-11-06 |first=Inal |last=Ersan}} On 16 November, Yemen forces killed two Houthi commanders, Abbas Aaida and Abu Haider. On 19 November, Yemeni forces took control of al-Malaheez, killing the local commander Ali al-Qatwani.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=111684§ionid=351020206 |title=Saudi soldier, Houthi leaders killed in north Yemen |date=19 November 2009 |publisher=[[Press TV]] |accessdate=29 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112631/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=111684§ionid=351020206 |archivedate=15 July 2011 |df= }} Houthi leaders claim that [[United States]] involvement in the war started on 14 December 2009 when the US launched 28 air raids.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=113687§ionid=351020206|title='US fighter jets attack Yemeni fighters'|date=14 December 2009|publisher=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=29 December 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102021507/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=113687§ionid=351020206|archivedate=2 January 2010|df=}} At least 120 people were killed and 44 injured by the alleged US air raids on the regions of Amran, Hajjah and Sa'dah in northern Yemen. Houthis claimed air raids on 18 December killed 63 civilians, including 28 children and injured at least 90 people.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=114056§ionid=351020206|title=US air raids kill 63 civilians in Yemen|date=18 December 2009|publisher=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=29 December 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119072634/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=114056§ionid=351020206|archive-date=2016-01-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] claimed he had authorised the strikes against al-Qaeda.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/cruise-missiles-strike-yemen/story?id=9375236&page=1|title=Obama Ordered U.S. Military Strike on Yemen Terrorists|last=Ross|first=Brian|author2=Richard Esposito |author3=Matthew Cole |author4=Luis Martinez |author5=Kirit Radia |publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}} On 20 December, Saudi air strike killed some civilians. According to a spokesman for the Houthis, a Saudi attack killed 54 people in the town of Al Nadheer in the northern province of Sa'dah. The group also claimed that Saudi forces were advancing on the nearby town of Zawa, also in Sa'dah, and had fired more than 200 shells.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2009/1221/Saudi-air-strike-kills-Yemen-rebels-as-US-drawn-into-fight|title=Saudi air strike kills Yemen rebels as US drawn into fight|author=Liam Stack|date=21 December 2009|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=17 October 2014}} On 22 December, the Houthis stated that they managed to repulse Saudi Arabian forces trying to infiltrate into the province of Sa'dah, killing an unspecified number of Saudi soldiers in a battle in the border region.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=114429§ionid=351020206|title=Houthis repel Saudi incursion into northern Yemen|date=23 December 2009|publisher=Press TV}} The fighting between Yemeni and Saudi forces and Houthis killed at least 119 Yemeni government forces, 263 Houthis, 277 civilians and 7 foreign civilians. Saudi casualties were confirmed at 82 at the time.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=115982§ionid=351020205|title=Saudi Arabia says soldiers killed in Yemen|date=12 January 2010|publisher=Press TV|access-date=2010-01-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119072634/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=115982§ionid=351020205|archive-date=2016-01-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} With more soldiers killed in subsequent clashes and missing soldiers being found dead, however, the casualties rose to 133 killed by 22 January 2010. The number of missing was put at six.[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3838344,00.html Saudi: Bodies of 20 soldiers found on Yemen border], 23 January 2010. In early January 2010, the Houthis chose the Iraqi cleric [[Grand Ayatollah]] [[Ali al-Sistani]] to mediate in their political standoff with the Yemeni government and to find a solution to the conflict. This choice was criticized by Saudi cleric Mohammad al-Arifi, a preacher at Riyadh's central mosque, who dismissed al-Sistani as "an infidel and debauched." The remarks by the Saudi cleric were considered extremely insulting by Shi'as around the world, causing major outrage in some Shi'a dominant countries like Iraq, Iran and Lebanon.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/salafis-irate-over-ban-on-preacher|title=Salafis irate over ban on preacher|work=The National|accessdate=17 October 2014}}[http://www.yalibnan.com/2010/01/07/sunni-scholars-against-insulting-sistani/ Sunni scholars against insulting Sistani] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717180520/http://www.yalibnan.com/2010/01/07/sunni-scholars-against-insulting-sistani/ |date=July 17, 2011 }} On 13 January 2010, [[Operation Blow to the Head]] was launched in an attempt by the government to capture the city of Sa'adah. Security forces claimed they killed 34 and arrested at least 25 Houthis, as well as killing al-Qaeda in Yemen leader [[Abdullah al-Mehdar]] in the next two weeks of fighting.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1242847/Al-Qaeda-Yemen-Leader-killed-gun-battle.html |location=London |work=Daily Mail |title=Leader of Al Qaeda in Yemen 'killed in gun battle' |date=2010-01-13}} On 25 January 2010, the Houthis offered a truce.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117035§ionid=351020206|title=Houthis initiate truce with Saudi Arabia|date=25 January 2010|publisher=Press TV|access-date=2010-01-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112823/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117035§ionid=351020206|archive-date=2011-07-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} Houthi leader Abdul Malek al-Houthi said they would stop fighting to prevent further civilian casualties and the withdrawal was a gesture for peace,{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117226§ionid=351020206|title=Saudis claim victory over Houthis|date=27 January 2010|publisher=Press TV|access-date=2010-01-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119072634/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117226§ionid=351020206|archive-date=2016-01-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} but warned that if the Saudis were to continue fighting the Houthis would go over into open warfare. A Saudi general announced that the Houthis had stopped fighting and were not on Saudi land anymore and that in response the Saudis also stopped fighting saying, "The battle has ended by God's will." But the Saudi king denied the Houthis had withdrawn saying they were forced out, and declared military victory for the end of their conflict with the Houthis.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/01/2010127124547864341.html|title=Saudi-Houthi border fighting ends|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=17 October 2014}} There have however been allegations that the Saudis launched new air raids on 29 January, thus breaking the truce.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117324§ionid=351020206|title=Despite truce call, Saudis pound northern Yemen|date=29 January 2010|publisher=Press TV|access-date=2010-01-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119072634/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117324§ionid=351020206|archive-date=2016-01-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} On 1 January the Yemeni government offered a conditional cease-fire. The cease-fire had five conditions which were the re-establishment of safe passage on roads, the surrender of mountain strongholds, a full withdrawal from all local authority property, the return of all military and public equipment seized during hostilities and the release of all the detained civilians and soldiers. On 30 January, Abdel-Malek al-Houthi released a video wherein he blamed the government for the recent round of fighting but said that: "Nevertheless, and for the fourth time, I announce our acceptance of the [government's] five conditions [for an end to the conflict] after the aggression stops ... the ball is now in the other party's court."[[Al Jazeera]] [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/01/2010130162418278418.html Yemen rebels renew ceasefire offer], January 30, 2010. After the truce was accepted on 30 January, however, there were still some clashes between the Houthis and both Saudi and Yemeni forces.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117423§ionid=351020206 Saudis 'launch 17 air raids' on Houthis] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112639/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117423§ionid=351020206 |date=2011-07-15 }}, 30 January 2010. Therefore, on 31 January the Yemeni government rejected the truce and launched a new round of attacks, killing 24 people.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117499§ionid=351020206 Yemen rejects Houthis' 4th peace offer] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112643/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=117499§ionid=351020206 |date=2011-07-15 }}, 31 January 2009. ===2010 conflict with pro-government tribes=== In April, Houthi spokesman Mohammed Abdulsalam declared that rebels had captured the [[Manaba district]] in Sa'dah, with little government resistance. Government troops declared they had killed 30 Houthis who had tried to penetrate into [[Harf Sufyan District]]. On July 17, 2010, the Houthis warned on their website that the government was preparing for another offensive against the Houthis. They said the government had been digging trenches from the Sana'a to Sa'ada. They claimed the army was trying to amass servicemen in villages and that soldiers in Amshia Bsfian region were creating an army stronghold on Mount Guide. The report came as the Yemeni government blamed Houthi fighters for recent ethnic clashes which had killed 11 people, including two soldiers, and for the kidnapping of two people in a market. The Houthis have denied these allegations and have claimed that it was the work of the government.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135298 'Yemen preparing to attack Houthis'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112648/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135298 |date=2011-07-15 }}, 18 July 2010. On July 20, 2010, clashes broke out between Houthis and members of an army-backed tribe, led by [[Sheikh Sagheer Aziz]], in the region of Souffian. A Houthi commander declared that the clashes had broken out because of Yemeni Army attacks on Houthis and local pro-Houthi tribes. Forty-nine people were reported killed in the clashes, including 20 tribal and 10 Houthi fighters. The Houthis also managed to surround the Yemeni military bases in the region.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135669§ionid=351020206 Fresh clashes claim 49 in north Yemen] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812183645/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135669§ionid=351020206 |date=2010-08-12 }}, 21 July 2010. Over the following days the Yemeni army and pro-government Bin Aziz tribes continued to clash with the Houthis. The government claimed that in the following two days, 20 fighters were killed on each side. A Houthi spokesman denied these claims, stating only three Houthi fighters had been killed in the clashes. Both sides have blamed each other for starting the clashes.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135794§ionid=351020206 More people killed in N Yemen clashes] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812183043/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135794§ionid=351020206 |date=2010-08-12 }}, 22 July 2010. The UN expressed great concern about the situation in North Yemen.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=136002§ionid=351020206 UN concerned about Yemen situation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812184900/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=136002§ionid=351020206 |date=2010-08-12 }}, 24 July 2010. On July 23, Houthi spokesman [[Vayf-Allah al-Shami]] said calm had returned to the region and that a government committee was trying to mediate a cease-fire between the Houthis and the Bin Aziz tribes in the Souffian region.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135949§ionid=351020206 Calm to return to north Yemen] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812184438/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=135949§ionid=351020206 |date=2010-08-12 }}, 23 July 2010. On July 27, Houthis seized a military post at al-Zaala in Harf Sufyan, capturing 200 soldiers of the army's [[Republican Guard (Yemen)|Republican Guard]]. Tribal sources claimed they had inflicted 200 fatalities on the Houthis in al-Amsheya while suffering only 30 dead themselves. Houthi spokesman [[Abdul Salam]] denied the high number of killed and said the claims were highly exaggerated. Houthis said they recovered the bodies of 17 of their fighters, including that of rebel commander Abu Haidar, near the house of Sheikh Saghir Aziz in Al-Maqam, near Al-Zaala.[[Google News]] [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jIwHpdctRI9A8uj8SDEWGUeegxYw Yemen Shiite rebels capture 200 soldiers: military official], 27 July 2010. On July 29, the Houthis released the 200 soldiers they had captured as a goodwill gesture. In total some 70 people had died since the clashes started.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=136618§ionid=351020206 Houthis release 200 Yemeni soldiers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812183149/http://presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=136618§ionid=351020206 |date=2010-08-12 }}, 29 July 2010. On November 22, one soldier was killed and two wounded in a roadside bombing. The next day 23 Houthi fighters and supporters were killed and 30 injured by a car bomb targeting a Shi'a religious procession in al-Jawf province.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/152295.html|title=Car bomb kills 23 in northern Yemen|date=24 November 2010|publisher=Press TV}}{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail/152771.html|title=Bomb kills Shia mourners in N Yemen|date=26 November 2010|publisher=Press TV}} On November 26, two Shi'a mourners were killed and eight injured by a bomb while on their way to Sa'adah city to attend [[Badreddin al-Houthi]]'s funeral. In total, between 195 and 281 people were killed during this round violence, with the majority of the casualties on the Houthi side.{{cite web|url=http://www.ploughshares.ca/content/yemen-2004-first-combat-deaths|title=Yemen (2004 – first combat deaths)|publisher=Ploughshares.ca|accessdate=17 October 2014}} ===2011 Yemeni Revolution=== {{main|Yemeni Revolution}} A major demonstration by over 16,000 protestors took place in [[Sana'a]] on 27 January.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0127/breaking26.html| title=Yemenis in anti-president protest| work=[[Irish Times]]| date=January 27, 2011}} On 2 February, President Saleh announced he would not run for reelection in 2013 and that he would not pass power to his son. On 3 February, 20,000 people protested against the government in Sana'a,{{cite news|last=Daragahi |first=Borzou |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/middleeast/la-fg-yemen-rallies-20110204,0,7940190.story |title=Yemen, Middle East: Tens of thousands stage rival rallies in Yemen |publisher=latimes.com |date=2011-02-03|accessdate=2011-02-04}}{{cite news|author=Lina Sinjab |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12353479 |title=Yemen protests: 20,000 call for President Saleh to go |publisher=BBC News |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-02-04}} and others in Aden,{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201123105140512715.html |title=Opposing protesters rally in Yemen |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=2011-02-04}} in a "Day of Rage" called for by [[Tawakel Karman]].{{cite news|title=New protests erupt in Yemen |date=2011-01-29 |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129112626339573.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w8S9MZ1r?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129112626339573.html |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no |df= }} On the same day, soldiers, armed members of the [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] and many others held a pro-government counter-demonstration in Sana'a.{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2011/02/03/salehpartisans-take-over-yemen-protestsite-aid0126.html |title=Saleh partisans take over Yemen protest site |publisher=Oneindia News |accessdate=2011-02-04}} On February 27, Abdul Malik al-Houthi announced support for the pro-democracy protests and the effort to effect regime change, as had happened in [[Tunisia]] and [[Egypt]]. Following these statements, large crowds of Houthis joined in protests across Northern Yemen.[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166419.html PressTV - Houthis join protests in north Yemen] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225012535/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166419.html |date=February 25, 2011 }} Houthi fighters entered [[Sadah|Sa'ada]] on March 19,{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=4276&MainCat=6|title=Sa'ada: A Cry for Help- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} engaging in a drawn out battle with the pro-government forces of Sheikh Uthman Mujalli.{{cite web|url=http://nationalyemen.com/2011/03/29/houthis-control-sa%E2%80%99ada-help-appoint-governor/ |title=Houthis Control Sa'ada, Help Appoint Governor |publisher=Nationalyemen.com |date=2011-03-29 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} They seized control of the city on March 24, after destroying Sheikh Mujalli's house and forcing the local governor to flee. The Houthis established military checkpoints at the entrances to the city after police deserted their posts and were relocated to army camps elsewhere. On March 26, Houthi rebels declared the creation of their own administration in [[Saada Governorate]], independent from Yemeni authorities. A former arms dealer was appointed governor by the Houthis, the previous governor having fled to Sanaa. On July 8, 23 people were killed in fighting between the Houthis and the opposition Islah party in al-Jawf governorate. The fighting erupted after the governor of al-Jawf fled, opposition tribes took control of the governorate, and the Houthis refused to hand over a Yemeni military base which they had seized several months earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/factional-fighting-brings-yemen-unrest-nearer-saudi-doorstep|title=Thomson Reuters Foundation|publisher=Trust.org|accessdate=17 October 2014}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Fighting continued until July 11, with more than 30 people killed.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=3805|title=Tens Killed as Battles between Tribes, Houthis Resume in Yemen - Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} The Houthis claimed that some elements of the pro-Islah militias had links to al-Qaeda.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/WTARC/2011/me_yemen0903_07_20.asp |title=Lack of authority in northern Yemen seen as 'golden opportunity' for Iran |work=World Tribune |date=2011-07-20 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} On July 28, over 120 people were killed as the Houthis launched an offensive to take over government buildings in al-Jawf.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=3858|title=Yemeni Revolution Slowly entering Phase of War- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Fighting in Jawf lasted for four months, in which time Sunni tribes claimed to have killed 470 Houthis, while acknowledging 85 casualties of their own.{{cite web|url=http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2011/10/03/houthis-vs-islah-in-al-jawf/|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20111004114436/http://armiesofliberation.com/archives/2011/10/03/houthis-vs-islah-in-al-jawf/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=4 October 2011|title=Houthis vs. Islah in al Jawf|publisher=Armiesofliberation.com|accessdate=17 October 2014|df=}} The Houthis eventually took control of al-Jawf governorate.{{cite web|url=http://www.islamtimes.org/vdcirrazyt1azq2.ilct.html |title=Houthis Close to Control Hajjah Governorate, Amid Expectations of Expansion of Control over Large Parts of Northern Yemen |work=Islam Times |date=2011-11-09 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} In August a car-bombing killed 14 Houthis in al-Jawf. {{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-08/15/c_131048789.htm|title=Suspected al-Qaida car bomb kills 14 Shi'ite Houthi rebels in Yemen: official|publisher=News.xinhuanet.com|accessdate=17 October 2014}} Although the Houthis initially blamed the US and Israel for the bombing, [[al-Qaeda]] eventually claimed responsibility,[http://www.newsyemen.net/en/view_news.asp?sub_no=3_2010_11_29_40210 Al-Qaeda claims attacks on Houthis in northern Yemen] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110801002924/http://www.newsyemen.net/en/view_news.asp?sub_no=3_2010_11_29_40210 |date=August 1, 2011 }} the organization having declared a holy war against the Houthis earlier that year.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=3077|title=Al-Qaeda Announces Holy War against Houthis- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} In early November clashes erupted between Houthis and a [[Salafi]] group in Sa'dah, leaving one Salafist dead.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=4273&MainCat=3|title=Clashes in Sa'ada Between Houthis and Salafis- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} On November 9, after several days of heavy fighting, the Houthis managed to break through defense lines of the pro-government Kashir and Aahm tribes in [[Hajjah Governorate]], seizing control of the [[Kuhlan Ash Sharaf District]] and advancing towards the port of [[Midi District|Midi]], thereby gaining access to the sea. Through Hajjah, the Houthis would be able to launch an assault on the Yemeni capital Sana'a.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=4288&MainCat=3|title=Al-Houthi Expansion Plan in Yemen Revealed- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} By taking Kuhlan Ash Sharaf, the Houthis managed to gain control over a highway linking San'a to the sea. On November 15, clashes between Houthis and Islah party militia restarted in al-Jawf, after an Islah party member tried to blow himself up during the al-Ghadeer festival, in [[Al Maton District]] but was captured and killed by the Houthis. A total of 10 people died in the ensuing fighting.{{cite web|url=http://english.cri.cn/6966/2011/11/15/2941s667225.htm |title=10 Killed in Clashes in N Yemen |publisher=English.cri.cn |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} On December 19, Houthis stormed a Sunni Islamist school in the [[Shaharah District]] of 'Amran governorate, injuring one teacher and expelling all teachers and students from the school. Houthis then took up positions inside the school.{{cite web |url=http://www.alsahwa-yemen.net/arabic/subjects/5/2011/12/19/14783.htm |title=الصحوة نت - Houthi militants storm school in Amran |publisher=Alsahwa-yemen.net |date=2011-12-19 |accessdate=2015-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305172017/http://www.alsahwa-yemen.net/arabic/subjects/5/2011/12/19/14783.htm |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }} On 23 November, Saleh signed a power-transfer agreement brokered by the Gulf Cooperation Council in Riyadh, under which he would transfer his power to his Vice-President within 30 days and leave his post as [[President of Yemen|president]] by February 2012, in exchange for immunity from prosecution.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Nov-23/154953-yemens-saleh-signs-deal-to-quit-power.ashx#axzz1eXuReO4L|title=Yemen's Saleh signs deal to quit power|work=The Daily Star Newspaper |accessdate=17 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/2011112355040101606.html|title=Yemen leader signs power-transfer deal|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=17 October 2014}} Although the GCC deal was accepted by the JMP, it was rejected by many of the protesters and the Houthis.{{cite web|url=http://www.yobserver.com/front-page/10021706.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130105161736/http://www.yobserver.com/front-page/10021706.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-05 |title=Process of withdrawing troops and armed tribesmen started for enhancing peace and normalizing life in Yemen |publisher=Yobserver.com |accessdate=2012-11-07 }}{{cite web|url=http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9007278114 |title=Houthis' Leader: US, Allies Plot to Spark Sectarian Rift in Yemen |publisher=Fars News Agency |date=2011-12-20 |accessdate=2012-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120601051013/http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9007278114 |archivedate=2012-06-01 |df= }} A [[Yemeni presidential election, 2012|presidential election]] was held in Yemen on 21 February 2012. With a reported 65 percent turnout, Abdrabbuh Mansur al-Hadi won 99.8% of the vote, and took the oath of office in Yemen's parliament on 25 February 2012. Saleh returned home the same day to attend Hadi's presidential inauguration.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/26/world/middleeast/abed-rabu-mansour-hadi-sworn-in-as-yemens-new-president.html|accessdate=15 August 2012|work=The New York Times|title=Yemen Swears In New President to the Sound of Applause, and Violence|first=Laura|last=Kasinof|date=27 February 2012}} After months of protests, Saleh had resigned from the presidency and formally transferred power to his successor, marking the end of his 33-year rule.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iqhKKOqo6XDujeTI_yaD4B0CcyVA?docId=CNG.12cc0199ecc6457c2d2a25874218f73d.691 |title=Yemen's Saleh formally steps down after 33 years |agency=AFP |date=2012-02-27 |accessdate=2012-11-07}} Throughout the year, some 200 people were killed in clashes between Houthis and Salafi militias in Sa'dah province.[http://www.yobserver.com/local-news/10022300.html Situations calm down in north of Yemen after 16 fighters killed] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130210092650/http://www.yobserver.com/local-news/10022300.html |date=2013-02-10 }} ===Post–Saleh (2012–2015)=== On February 26, 2012, heavy fighting occurred in Hajjah governorate as Houthis fought Sunni tribesmen loyal to the Al-Islah party. At least seven fighters from the Hojjor tribe were killed and nine others injured, while in the Ahem area nine bodies were found, belonging to Houthi fighters. Houthis launched an assault backed by artillery on al-Jarabi area, al-Hazan village, al-Moshaba mountain, and Ahem police station to take control of the al-Moshaba mountain. Parts of the [[Kushar District]] were put under siege{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=4801|title=Sectarian clashes continue in north Yemen, dozens killed - Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} since clashes erupted in that province between Houthis and the al-Zakari tribe in November.{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenfox.net/news_details.php?sid=997 |title=Two Houthis killed in clashes with Hajjah tribesmen |publisher=Yemen Fox |date=2011-11-21 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} In early February, over 55 people had been killed during sectarian violence in Kushar.{{cite web|url=http://www.uruknet.info/?new=85475 |title=Sectarian clashes continue in north Yemen, at least 55 killed |publisher=www.uruknet.info |date= |accessdate=2015-01-24}} During February and March some 27 people were killed and 36 injured due to mines in Hajjah. A total of 600 were killed in clashes in Hajjah between November 2011 and April 2012, mainly in Kushar and [[Mustaba District]]s.{{cite web|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/topic,45a5199f2,45dd59222,4f9908df2,0,,,.html |title=Yemen: Rising landmine death toll in Hajjah Governorate |publisher=UNHCR |date=2012-04-18 |accessdate=2015-01-24}} On March 8, a high-ranking military commander and six of his bodyguards were killed by Houthi gunmen in the northern province of Amran.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=4874|title=Yemen: military commander, six bodyguards killed by Houthis- Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} On March 23, a suicide bomber targeted a Houthi march in Sa'dah, no casualties were reported.{{cite news| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-25/news/sns-rt-us-yemen-bombingbre84o0nm-20120525_1_suicide-bomber-houthis-explosive-belt |work=Chicago Tribune |title=Suicide bomber kills 12 in northern Yemen |date=2012-05-25}} On March 25, some 14 people were killed and three injured in a car bombing in [[Al Hazm District|al-Hazm]] of al-Jawf province, targeting a Shi'a gathering near a school.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-291146343.html|title=Suicide bombing kills 14 Houthis in Al-Jawf.|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Another 8 Houthis were killed in an attack by Salafis on April 21.[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/237341.html PressTV - Salafi attack on Houthis kills eight in Yemen] From June 2 to June 4, Houthis clashed with Salafi militias in Kataf district leaving several dead.{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=5492|title=Clashes renewed between Houthis and Salfis - Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Houthis claim to have taken over three Salafi positions and confiscated Saudi weapons during the clash.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120620020148/http://www.yobserver.com/front-page/10022087.html Houthis take control of three positions in north Yemen, claim confiscating Saudi weapons] On August 21, clashes broke out between Houthis and tribes in [[Ash Shahil District]] of Hajjah after Houthis allegedly shot two women in the district. As the fighting broke out, Houthis retreated from al-Amroor area and retreated to the mountains between Janeb al-Sham and Janeb al-Yemen. Houthis were said to control several mountains in the region including mount Azzan and the governorate center that overlooks [[Al Mahabishah District|al-Mahabishah]], [[Qafl Shamer District|Qafl Shamer]] and [[Ku'aydinah District]]s. A truce was signed between the two sides on August 30.{{cite web|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1603/news/1322/Truce-shook-on-between-Houthis-Al-Shahel-tribesmen-in-Hajja.htm|title=Truce shook on between Houthis, Al-Shahel tribesmen in Hajja|work=Yemen Times|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Clashes reignited on September 6 and Houthis managed to seize control of five schools, a medical center and a police station. Some 30 people were killed in the battles.{{cite web|url=http://yemenpost.net/Detail123456789.aspx?ID=3&SubID=5950|title=Houthis Fight Tribes, Take over Schools, Public Offices in Yemen, Site - Yemen Post English Newspaper Online|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Afterwards Houthis claimed civilian areas were being shelled by al-Islah, while MP Ali al-Ma'amari accused Houthis of killing a worker from [[Taiz]].[http://fnayemen.com/index.php/news/security/260-amran-houthis-islah-exchange-accusations-on-death-of-worker Amran: Houthis, Islah exchange accusations on death of worker] In September and October, Houthis led many protests in Sana'a as part of the [[Reactions to Innocence of Muslims|2012 Anti-US protests]] caused by the release of [[Innocence of Muslims]]. Houthi slogans were hung all across the old city of Sana'a and Shi'a majority areas during the protests.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/03/yemen-houthis-idUSL6E8KU2WU20121003 |agency=Reuters |first=Andrew |last=Hammond |title=FEATURE-Houthi rebels seen gaining new influence in Yemen |date=2012-10-03}} This has led to Houthis expanding their control in [[Sana'a Governorate]] and other areas around the capital, particularly [[Khwlan District|Khwlan]] and [[Sanhan District]]s and the town [[Shibam Kawkaban District|Shibam Kawkaban]] in [[Al Mahwit Governorate|al-Mahwit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenfox.net/news_details.php?sid=4673|title=Yemen Fox- Houthis seek to take control over Sana'a|author=Yemen Fox|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Al-Juraf district was also named as a Houthi stronghold, where they had large numbers of weapons stationed. Sunni sources have alleged that Houthis have used the protests to smuggle weapons and fighters from areas surrounding Sana'a into Sana'a city itself, mainly in the old city.{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenfox.net/articles.php?id=880|title=Yemen Fox- Mohammed Jumaih - Houthis in Sana'a|author=Yemen Fox|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} During one of the protests, in [[Raydah District|Raydah]], Amran, clashes broke out between Houthis and Islahi gunmen after the Islahi gunmen interrupted a Houthi mass rally, denouncing Innocence of Muslims and the US government, on September 21. Two people were killed during the clash and three Islahi gunmen were captured. Fighting continued until September 23, leaving 16 fighters dead and 36 Islah men captured by the Houthis. After a cease-fire was agreed on, Houthis withdrew from the town and released the prisoners they had taken. A group of Houthis remained in Owaidan mosque.{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenfox.net/news_details.php?sid=4311|title=Yemen Fox- Mediation ends war, drives Houthis out of Raida|author=Yemen Fox|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} ===2014–15: Victory for the insurgency=== {{main|Battle of Sana'a (2014)|Houthi takeover in Yemen}} On 18 August 2014, the Houthis began a series of demonstrations in Sana'a against increased fuel prices. On 21 September, the Houthis [[Battle of Sana'a (2014)|took control]] of Sana'a, after which Prime Minister [[Mohammed Basindawa]] resigned and the Houthis signed a deal for a new unity government with other political parties. The protests were marked by clashes between the Houthis and the government and also clashes between the Houthis and [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]].{{cite news|title=Frank Gardner: Yemen at risk of civil war, says ambassador|author=Frank Gardner|publisher=BBC|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-29749046|accessdate=29 October 2014|date=24 October 2014}} At least 340 people were killed on the outskirts of the Yemeni capital in one week of fighting between the Shiite rebels and Sunni militiamen before the city fell.{{cite web|url=http://dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Sep-22/271549-at-least-200-killed-in-recent-yemen-fighting-ministry.ashx#axzz3E3iuXhsm|title=At least 340 killed in Yemen's week-long fighting|work=The Daily Star Newspaper}} The new government was sworn in on 9 November, although the Houthis and [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] announced they would not take part.{{cite news|title=Yemen swears in new government amid boycott|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/11/yemen-swear-new-government-2014118223745207779.html|accessdate=14 November 2014|date=9 November 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera}} A spokesman for the Houthi group has accused Yemen's President Hadi of arming members of Al-Qaeda in the Marib province, east of the country, in order to create a new security crisis.{{cite web|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/16422-houthis-accuse-yemens-president-of-arming-al-qaeda|title=Houthis accuse Yemen's president of arming Al-Qaeda|work=Middle East Monitor - The Latest from the Middle East|accessdate=22 March 2015}} The crisis intensified as Houthi militants attacked the presidential palace and private residence in January 2015, quickly seizing control of both. On 22 January, President [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] and his ministers resigned.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2015-01-22/yemen-rebels-reach-deal-with-hadi-to-pull-back-from-palace-1-.html|title=Yemen President Hadi Resigns After Shiite Rebels Seize Palace|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=22 January 2015|agency=Bloomberg}} The Houthis declared themselves in full control of the government on 6 February, dissolving parliament and putting a [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] led by [[Mohammed Ali al-Houthi]] in charge of the country.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/yemens-shia-rebels-finalize-coup-vow-to-dissolve-parliament/article22829401/|work=The Globe and Mail|title=Yemen's Shia rebels finalize coup, vow to dissolve parliament|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}} ===Aftermath=== {{main|Aftermath of the Houthi takeover in Yemen}} {{see also|2015 military intervention in Yemen {{!}}Operation Decisive Storm}} Hadi escaped from house arrest on 21 February and made his way to [[Aden]], where he renounced his resignation, condemned the Houthi takeover, and attempted to reassemble his government. He declared Aden to be Yemen's provisional capital. [[Battle of Aden Airport|Fighting broke out]] over [[Aden International Airport]] on 19 March after Hadi dismissed a general in Aden, [[Abdul-Hafez al-Saqqaf]], whom he suspected of being loyal to [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], widely believed to be an ally of the Houthis.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/03/19/southern-yemen-clashes/25006201/|agency=USA TODAY|title=Clashes force closure of Yemen's Aden airport|first=Jane|last=Onyanga-Omara|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015}} The next day, [[2015 Sana'a mosque bombings|a quadruple suicide bombing]] ripped through two mosques in [[Sana'a]] while hundreds of Houthis were praying there. The Revolutionary Committee declared a "state of general mobilisation" in response to the events and launched a military offensive directed at Hadi's holdouts, whom the Houthis accused of being in league with [[al-Qaeda]].{{cite news|url=http://sabanews.net/ar/news391987.htm|language=Arabic|title=اللجنة الثورية تعلن التعبئة العامة وتوجه الأمن والجيش القيام بواجبه للتصدي للإرهابيين|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015|agency=Saba News Agency}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/faa645dc-d0b2-11e4-982a-00144feab7de.html|agency=Financial Times|title=Q&A: Yemen's slide into civil war|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}} Since the clashes at the airport and the Houthis' southward offensive, the media has increasingly described the deteriorating situation in Yemen and the escalating clashes between the two factions claiming to represent the legitimate government as a [[Yemeni civil war (2015–present)|civil war]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/yemen-crisis-shortage-of-water-and-medical-supplies-threatens-civilians-caught-up-in-devastating-civil-war-10163600.html|agency=The Independent|title=Yemen crisis: Shortage of water and medical supplies threatens civilians caught up in devastating civil war|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Security-Watch/terrorism-security/2015/0407/Warnings-of-humanitarian-crisis-as-Yemen-s-civil-war-rolls-on-video|agency=The Christian Science Monitor|title=Warnings of humanitarian crisis as Yemen's civil war rolls on (+video)|first=Michael|last=Holtz|date=7 April 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/04/06/world/yemenis-forced-take-sea-aden-civil-war-rages-ancient-port/#.VSYN-fnF9ps|first=Sami|last=Aboudi|agency=Japan Times|title=Yemenis forced to take to sea from Aden as civil war rages through ancient port}} Several states led by [[Saudi Arabia]] also mounted a [[2015 military intervention in Yemen|military intervention in Yemen]] codenamed "Operation Decisive Storm". The Saudi-led coalition sided with Hadi's government in Aden, shelling Houthi positions from land and sea and hitting them with airstrikes.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/03/saudi-ambassador-announces-military-operation-yemen-150325234138956.html|title=Saudi and Arab allies bomb Houthi positions in Yemen|newspaper=Al Jazeera|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} ===Missile attacks on Saudi territory=== On May 19, 2017 Saudi Arabia intercepted a Houthi-fired ballistic missile targeting, a deserted area south of the Saudi capital and most populous city Riyadh.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/saudi-arabia-intercepts-houthi-rebel-missile-fired-towards-riyadh/a-38913313|title=Saudi Arabia intercepts Houthi rebel missile fired towards Riyadh - News - DW - 20.05.2017|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/saudi-arabia-retaliates-rocket-attack-houthis-47528517|title=ABC News|first=ABC|last=News|website=ABC News}}{{cite web|title = فيديو+صور "قاهر1" أول صاروخ بالستي معدل محلياً يضرب قاعدة خميس مشيط {{!}} المسيرة نت - قناة المسيرة الفضائية |url = http://www.almasirah.net/%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%B1-%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B11-%D8%A3%D9%88%D9%84-%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%AE-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%AF%D9%84-%D9%85/ | access-date = 10 March 2016 }} This missile attack was followed by another one on 27 October 2016, allegedly aimed towards the [[Great Mosque of Mecca|Holy Mosque]] in [[Mecca]] (''"Makkah Al-Mukarramah, the prayer direction of Muslims and the Cradle of Revelation"''), which was condemned by a special Emergency Meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Member States of the [[Organization of Islamic Cooperation]] (OIC) on 17 November 2017. On 19 December 2017, a direct attack on Riyadh by another ballistic missile was intercepted, allegedly''"Iranian-made"'', launched by''"Iranian-supported rebels"'' and aimed at the Saudi royal palace.[''Rebels in Yemen Fire Second Ballistic Missile at Saudi Capital'' https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/19/world/middleeast/yemen-rebels-missile-riyadh.html][''Saudi Arabia shoots down Houthi missile aimed at Riyadh palace'' https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/19/saudis-shoot-down-houthi-missile-close-to-capital-riyadh][''Yemen rebel ballistic missile intercepted over Riyadh'' https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42412729] Another special Extraordinary Meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Member States of the OIC on 21 January 2018 in [[Jeddah]] condemned the attack, decrying it as an aggression on the KSA, and taking it as ''"evidence of the Iranian-backed Houthi militias' refusal to cooperate with the international community and accept international resolutions"'', referring to the resolution adopted in the Mecca Conference in November 2016 and relevant [[UN Security Council]] resolutions. ==Alleged foreign involvement== ===Iran and Hezbollah=== There have been a number of allegations that [[Iran]] and [[Hezbollah]] have intervened to aid the Houthis, including: * The Saudi and Yemeni governments both accuse Iran of helping the Houthis.
