Iran, they say, has secretly landed arms on the Red Sea coast. In October, 2009, Yemen's government said its navy intercepted an arms-carrying Iranian vessel. Yemen's state-controlled press claims Houthi rebels have been trained in an Iranian-run camp across the Red Sea in [[Eritrea]]. Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, says members of Lebanon's Iran-backed Hezbollah militia are teaching them. The Yemeni authorities also darkly note that the Houthis' long-time leader, Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi, who died in battle in 2004, used to visit [[Qom]], one of Shia Islam's holiest places.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/middleeast-africa/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14920092|title=Yemen's war: Pity those caught in the middle|work=The Economist|accessdate=17 October 2014}} None of these accusations have yet been borne out by independent observers and the Iranians deny any involvement. * Saudi-owned [[Al Arabiya]] claimed that "well-informed sources" are saying that "the president of the former [[Democratic Republic of Yemen|South Yemen]] ([[Ali Salim al-Beidh|Ali Salim al-Bidh]]) conducted a secret visit to the Lebanese capital [[Beirut]] last October (2009), and tried to contact figures close to Hezbollah aiming to win its support for the Houthi rebels, and for South (Yemen's) secession." The sources added that those Hezbollah-allied figures "informed al-Bidh that the party's top officials do not want to meet with him and that they do not approve the attribution of Hezbollah's name with what is happening in Yemen, or to appear as supporting to any rebellion." Ibrahim al-Mussawi, Head of Hezbollah's Media Unit, told Alarabiya.net that his party denies the report about an alleged secret visit.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/Lebanon/6DDAE71654CF04ECC225768600637583?OpenDocument|title=Hizbullah Denies Report about Former South Yemen President Visiting Beirut to Demand Support for Huthis|work=Naharnet|accessdate=17 October 2014}} * High-ranking officials from the [[Iranian Revolutionary Guard]] were said to have secretly met with Houthi rebels and Hezbollah in Yemen to coordinate joint military operations against Saudi positions along the border. Pan-Arab [[Asharq al-Awsat]] daily said Arab and Egyptian sources uncovered that a number of intelligence services in the region have learned of the three-way meeting which also aimed at developing a plan to escalate the military situation along the Saudi-Yemeni border. It said the high-level meeting which took place in November, 2009 was the most prominent evidence of "direct Iranian involvement" in the support of Houthi rebels financially, militarily and logistically.{{cite web|url=http://www.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/Lebanon/A857AE4FD533574CC225768B00262D5E?OpenDocument|title=Secret Meeting in Yemen between Iran, Huthi, Hizbullah Officials|work=Naharnet|accessdate=17 October 2014}} * Yemeni Foreign Minister [[Abu Bakr al-Qirbi]] on 13 December 2009 urged Iran to crack down on Iranian groups he accused of aiding Houthi rebels in northern Yemen and held Iran's government partly to blame. He said: "Religious (Shiite) circles and groups in Iran are providing aid to the Huthis," However, Iran has repeatedly denied such accusations.Yemeni FM: Iran Must Curb Groups Aiding Huthi Rebels{{cite news| url=http://www.naharnet.com/domino/tn/NewsDesk.nsf/MiddleEast/560D6BD248902E2DC225768B005434A3?OpenDocument| title=Yemeni FM: Iran Must Curb Groups Aiding Huthi Rebels| publisher=[[naharnet]]| date=2009-12-13| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.naharnet.com%2Fdomino%2Ftn%2FNewsDesk.nsf%2FMiddleEast%2F560D6BD248902E2DC225768B005434A3%3FOpenDocument+&date=2010-01-23| archivedate=2010-01-23| deadurl=yes| df=}} * On 25 May 2009, Iran first deployed warships to the [[Gulf of Aden]] to combat [[piracy in Somalia]]. On 18 November, a second group of Iranian warships came to the Gulf of Aden, at the same time as Saudi Arabia imposed a blockade on Houthi-controlled coasts and launched a crackdown on Houthi ships delivering weapons to the Houthis.{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,521730,00.html |publisher=Fox News |title=Iran Sends 6 Warships to International Waters in 'Saber Rattling' Move |date=2009-05-25}} Iran dispatched its 5th fleet to the Gulf of Aden.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=116618§ionid=351020101 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125172427/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=116618§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=2010-01-25 |df= }} Some have alleged that the [[Iranian Navy]] is operating there to help supply the Houthis with weapons and counter the Saudi naval power in the area rather than to fight Somali pirates. ===Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Jordan, Sudan, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates.=== Saudi Arabia has led a major military intervention in Yemen, and organized a coalition of other nations to support its efforts, including Egypt, Jordan, Sudan, and Bahrain.{{cite news | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/photo/2015/05/the-saudi-arabia-yemen-war-of-2015/392687/| title=The Saudi Arabia-Yemen War of 2015 | magazine = [[The Atlantic]] | date=2015-05-07}} ===United States=== In December 2009, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that the United States has provided weapons and logistical support to Yemeni government strikes against suspected hide-outs of Al Qaeda within its borders. The officials said that the American support was approved by President Obama and came at the request of the Yemeni government.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/19/world/middleeast/19yemen.html|title=U.S. Aids Yemeni Raids on Al Qaeda, Officials Say|last=Shanker|first=Thom|author2=Landler, Mark |date=18 December 2009 |work=[[New York Times]]}} Houthi leaders however claim that US involvement started on 14 December when the US launched 28 air raids. At least 120 people were killed and 44 injured by the alleged US air raids on the regions of Amran, Hajjah and Sa'ada in North Yemen, a Houthi leader was quoted as saying: "The US air force perpetrated an appalling massacre against citizens in the north of Yemen as it launched air raids on various populated areas, markets, refugee camps and villages along with Saudi warplanes, The savage crime committed by the US air force shows the real face of the United States. It cancels out much touted American claims of human rights protection, promotion of freedoms of citizens as well as democracy."{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=113854§ionid=351020206 |title=US fighters pound Sa'ada, kill 120 |date=16 December 2009 |publisher=[[Press TV]] |accessdate=29 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091219130445/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=113854§ionid=351020206 |archivedate=19 December 2009 |df= }} The Houthi claimed that new air raids on 18 December killed 63 civilians, including 28 children and injured at least 90 people. On June 17, 2011, following Friday prayers, tens of thousands of protestors rallied in [[Sa'dah]] against US interference in Yemen.''[[Tehran Times]]'' [http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=242672 Yemenis stage massive anti-U.S. rallies], June 18, 2011. The Houthis blamed US intelligence forces of carrying out a bombing in August 2011 which killed 14 Houthi fighters.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-08/15/c_131048789.htm|title=Suspected al-Qaida car bomb kills 14 Shi'ite Houthi rebels in Yemen: official|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2015}} ===Other=== * {{flag|Jordan}}: It has been alleged that Jordan deployed commandos to fight alongside the Saudis during their offensive in Northern [[Mount Al-Dukhan]] and that Saudis sent the Jordanian commandos to fight in Northern Yemen. They also sent auxiliary units to support Saudi forces.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=111852§ionid=351020206|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123155646/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=111852§ionid=351020206|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 November 2009|title=Jordanian commandos join war on Houthi fighters|date=21 November 2009|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}} By December 2009 it was alleged that over 2,000 Jordanian soldiers were fighting at the front. * {{flag|Morocco}}: It was alleged that Morocco have sent hundreds of elite fighters, mainly para-troopers trained for counter-insurgency operations, to aid the 2009–2010 Saudi offensive. * {{flag|Pakistan}}: Initially it was alleged in some news channels that the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan government]] had sent contingent of [[Special Services Group|special forces]] to join Yemeni counter insurgency operations in Sa'dah. However, [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan government]] has strongly rejected these rumors of sending Pakistani troops to join a Saudi-backed coalition forces fighting Houthi rebels in war-stricken Yemen. The official statement says [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan government]] is in favor of peaceful solution of this dispute.[[The News International|Daily The News]] [http://www.thenews.com.pk/article-179677-Pakistan-rejects-rumours-of-sending-troops-to-Yemen], 29 March 2015. ==Humanitarian effects== {{See also|Human rights violations during the Yemeni Civil War (2015-present)}} In April 2008, the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] estimated that the conflict had created 77,000 [[internally displaced persons]] (IDPs) in Sa'dah Governorate.{{cite news| title=YEMEN: Rebel leader calls for international aid| url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=78068| agency=[[IRIN]]| date=2008-05-06| accessdate=2008-05-23}} By order of then king [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia]], the Saudis were to shelter and build 10,000 new homes for the war-displaced people.{{cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/12/02/92985.html|title=Saudi king visits area of Yemen border conflict|date=2 December 2009|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1§ion=0&article=129019&d=3&m=12&y=2009|title=10,000 houses for Jazan displaced|date=3 December 2009|work=[[Arab News]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/NewsAgenciesPublicSite/ArticleDetails.aspx?Language=en&id=2044076|title=Saudi king orders construction of 10,000 houses for displaced people in south |date=2 December 2009|publisher=[[Kuwait News Agency]]|accessdate=29 December 2009}} ===Use of child soldiers=== {{See also|Military use of children}} [[UNICEF]] and [[Islamic Relief]] were reported as condemning Houthi rebels for abusing children by forcing them to fight for their cause.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/un-calls-for-the-prosecution-of-child-soldier-recruiters|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130114172550/http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/un-calls-for-the-prosecution-of-child-soldier-recruiters|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 January 2013|title=UN calls for the prosecution of child soldier recruiters|work=The National|accessdate=17 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2009/11/23/Issue-of-child-soldiers-raised-in-Yemen/UPI-70641258992863/|title=Issue of child soldiers raised in Yemen|work=UPI|accessdate=17 October 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6868811.ece|title=Yemen child soldier tells of his hatred for al-Houthi rebels|work=The Times|accessdate=17 October 2014}} In November 2009, over 400 children walked to the [[UNDP]] office in Sana'a, to protest against the alleged Houthi abuse of children's rights.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110405190852/http://www.yobserver.com/local-news/10017635.html Yemen children renews protest al-Houthi-related child abuse.] Allegations were made that both the Yemeni government and the Houthi rebels exploited the use of child soldiers during the war. Human Rights Watch noted difficulty in citing the exact numbers of child soldiers on the Houthis' part. However, there existed a significant amount of evidence that the government itself employed child soldiers in the ranks of the armed forces, the result of the country's lack of [[birth certificates]] and further documentation of age.{{cite news|title=All Quiet On The Northern Front? |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWFiles2010.nsf/FilesByRWDocUnidFilename/SMAR-84A9WN-full_report.pdf/$File/full_report.pdf |date=March 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-24 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100214/FOREIGN/702139832/1315 |title=UN calls for the prosecution of child soldier recruiters |publisher=The National |date=2010-02-13 |accessdate=2010-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119072633/http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100214%2FFOREIGN%2F702139832%2F1315 |archivedate=2016-01-19 |df= }} Where the Yemeni government was limited by restrictions, [[The Times]] reported on a fourteen-year-old boy who fought for a tribal militia sponsored by the government.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6868811.ece |title=Yemen child soldier tells of his hatred for al-Houthi rebels |publisher=The Times |date=2009-10-10 |accessdate=2010-09-24 | location=London | first=Judith | last=Evans}} A Sana'a-based human rights group, Seyaj Organization for Childhood Protection, noted that the Houthis were mainly responsible, stating that fifty-percent of the rebels were under the age of eighteen. It is estimated that anywhere between 400 and 500 children are killed every year in Yemen as the result of tribal conflict.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2010/01/06/Yemens-child-soldiers-go-to-war/UPI-89571262808410/ |title=Yemen's child soldiers go to war |publisher=UPI |date=2010-01-06 |accessdate=2010-09-19}} The same organization eventually released a report claiming that 700 children were used as soldiers by the Houthis and pro-government militias during the war. The report concluded that 187 children were killed during the conflict, 71% as the result of the fighting.{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100225/FOREIGN/702249829/1002 |title=Both sides in war blamed for Yemen's dead children |publisher=The National |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301102501/http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100225%2FFOREIGN%2F702249829%2F1002 |archivedate=2010-03-01 |df= }} These allegations were supported by the story of "Akram," a nine-year-old boy who was duped by a cousin to deliver a bomb to an unspecified target in the Old City of Saada. Akram, unknowingly wired with an explosive, was apprehended by police and taken to safety in Sana'a, along with his father. A day after telling his story at a press conference Akram's home was bombed in Saada City. His younger brother suffered injuries in the retaliation.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/world-news/the-children-of-yemen-s-tribal-war-1.990167 |title=The children of Yemen's tribal war |publisher=The Sunday Herald |date=2009-12-05 |accessdate=2010-09-19}} ==See also== {{Portal|Middle East|War}} * [[Human rights in Yemen]] * [[List of modern conflicts in the Middle East]] * [[Military of Yemen]] * [[South Yemen insurgency]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150216231342/http://midwestdiplomacy.com/2015/01/26/demystifying-yemens-conflict/ Demystifying Yemen's Conflict (Midwest Diplomacy)] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/country_profiles/1706450.stm Timeline: Yemen (BBC)] * [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=79410 YEMEN: The conflict in Saada Governorate – analysis], ''IRIN'', 24 July 2008 * [http://omergendler.blogspot.com/2009/08/yemen-micro-cosmoses-of-middle-east.html "Yemen A Microcosmos of the Middle East", "The Omer Gendler Watch" (August 25, 2009) - blog] * [https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/08/28/armed-conflict-northern-yemen Armed Conflict in Northern Yemen] (HRW) * [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/08/200981294214604934.html Profile: Yemen's Houthi fighters] * [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/frontline-fight-for-yemen/ The Fight for Yemen] (PBS Frontline) {{Terrorism in Yemen}} {{Yemen topics}} {{Ongoing military conflicts}} {{Post-Cold War Asian conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Houthi Insurgency In Yemen}} [[Category:2000s in Yemen]] [[Category:2010s in Yemen]] [[Category:2000s conflicts]] [[Category:2010s conflicts]] [[Category:National security in Yemen]] [[Category:Shia Islam in Yemen]] [[Category:Terrorism in Yemen]] [[Category:Wars involving Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Wars involving Yemen]] [[Category:Houthi insurgency in Yemen| ]] [[Category:Houthis|Insurgency]] [[Category:Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)]] [[Category:Rebellions in Yemen]] [[Category:Shia–Sunni sectarian violence]] [[Category:Resistance movements]] [[Category:Anti-ISIL factions]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist by the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Organizations designated as terrorist in Asia]]

renovated Peace Memorial Hall 1994 |location= 1-2 Nakajima-cho, [[Naka-ku, Hiroshima|Naka-ku]], [[Hiroshima]] |director= [[Koichiro Maeda]] |website= [http://www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp/top_e.html www.pcf.city.hiroshima.jp] }} The '''[[Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum]]''' is located in [[Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park]], in central [[Hiroshima]], [[Japan]]. It was established in August 24, 1955. The vision of the museum is the complete international abolition of all nuclear weapons, and the promotion of world peace. Fifty-three million people had visited the museum from its opening in 1955 through 2005. The number of visitors is over one million per year. Since the museum opened, there have been numerous visits, by heads of state, foreign dignitaries, political figures, peace activists, and various celebrities or other notable figures. {{Clear}} ==List of notable figures== {| border="1" class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" !Date!!Distinguished visitor!!Nationality!!remark, "Message for Peace" |- |October 9, 1957||[[Jawaharlal Nehru]] || {{flag|India}} || Prime Minister of India |- |December 9, 1958||[[Douglas MacArthur II]] || {{flag|US|1912}} || US Ambassador |- |July 26, 1959||[[Ernesto Guevara]] || {{flag|Argentina}} || visited as a Cuban ambassador The Japan Times [http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20080516a3.html Che Guevara's daughter visits bomb memorial in Hiroshima] retrieved 2011-7-26 |- |August 7, 1960||[[Akihito]] || {{flag|Japan}} || Crown Prince of Japan |- |April 16, 1963||[[Elisabeth Schwarzhaupt]] || {{flag|West Germany}} || Health Minister of West Germany |- |January 27, 1964||[[Baudouin of Belgium|Baudouin]] || {{flag|Belgium}} || King of Belgium |- |April 11, 1964||[[Richard Nixon]] || {{flag|US}} || visited four years before his Presidency and laid a wreath |- |June 19, 1964||[[Putra of Perlis|Syed Harun Putra]] || {{flag|Malaysia}} || Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia |- |March 19, 1965||[[Paolo Marella]] || {{flag|Vatican City}} || Ambassador of Holy See |- |October 31, 1965||[[Valentina Tereshkova]] || {{flag|USSR}} || Cosmonaut |- |October 10, 1966||[[Jean-Paul Sartre]] || {{flag|France}} || Philosopher, political activist |- |October 16, 1968||[[U. {{lead too short|date=January 2018}} '''Marxism–Leninism–Maoism''' ('''M–L–M''' or '''MLM''', formerly known as '''Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought''') is a [[political philosophy]] that builds upon [[Marxism–Leninism]] and some aspects of [[Maoism|Mao Zedong Thought]] which was first formalised in 1993 by the [[Revolutionary Internationalist Movement]].{{cite web|title=Long Live Marxism-Leninism-Maoism!|url=http://www.aworldtowin.org/back_issues/1995-20/ll_mlm_20_eng.htm|publisher=Revolutionary Internationalist Movement|accessdate=15 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140411203548/http://www.aworldtowin.org/back_issues/1995-20/ll_mlm_20_eng.htm|archivedate=April 11, 2014}} == Origin == {{Marxism–Leninism sidebar}} Maoism was considered synonymous with Mao Zedong Thought (also known as Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought) from the 1960s onwards—when many [[anti-revisionist]] [[Marxist]] organisations sided with China following the [[Sino-Soviet split]]—until 1993, when the [[Revolutionary Internationalist Movement]] (RIM) formalised Marxism–Leninism–Maoism as a new and higher stage of Marxism–Leninism.{{cite web|last1=Moufawad-Paul|first1=Joshua|title=Onwards Maoist Century!|url=http://moufawad-paul.blogspot.ca/2012/05/onwards-maoist-century.html?view=classic|accessdate=15 June 2014}}
{{cite web|title=Maoism today|url=http://www.pcr-rcp.ca/old/en/pwd/2f.php|website=PCR-RCP|accessdate=18 June 2014}}
{{cite web|title=International Situation of Marxism-Leninism-Maoism|url=http://mlmprincipallymaoism.wordpress.com/2013/01/14/international-situation-of-marxism-leninism-maoism/|accessdate=18 June 2014}}
{{cite web|title=Maoism or Trotskyism|url=http://www.systemiccapital.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/Maoism-or-Trotskyism.pdf|accessdate=18 June 2014}} This caused a split in the Maoist movement, with the adherents of Mao Zedong Thought leaving the RIM and congregating around the [[International Conference of Marxist–Leninist Parties and Organizations (International Newsletter)|International Conference of Marxist–Leninist Parties and Organizations]].{{cite web|last1=Cailmail|first1=Benoît|title=A History of Nepalese Maoism since its Foundation by Mohan Bikram Singh|url=http://himalaya.socanth.cam.ac.uk/collections/journals/ebhr/pdf/EBHR_33%2634_02.pdf|publisher=European Bulletin of Himalayan Research|accessdate=20 June 2014}} == Components == === Mass line === {{Maoism sidebar}} Building on the theory of the [[vanguard party]] by [[Vladimir Lenin]], the theory of the [[mass line]] outlines a strategy for the mass popularisation of revolutionary ideology, consolidation of the [[dictatorship of the proletariat]] and strengthening of the party and for the building of [[Socialist mode of production|socialism]]. The mass line can be summarised by the phrase "from the masses, to the masses". It has three components (or stages) as follows:{{cite web|title=Short Definitions of the 'Mass Line' and a 'Mass Perspective'|url=http://massline.info/sum1p.htm|website=massline.info|accessdate=15 June 2014}} # Gathering the diverse ideas of the masses. # Processing or concentrating these ideas from the perspective of revolutionary Marxism, in light of the long-term, ultimate interests of the masses (which the masses themselves may sometimes only dimly perceive) and in light of a scientific analysis of the objective situation. # Returning these concentrated ideas to the masses in the form of a political line which will actually advance the mass struggle toward [[revolution]]. These three steps should be applied over and over again, reiteratively uplifting practice and knowledge to higher and higher stages. === People's war === [[People's war]], a strategy for guerilla warfare, holds the following: * Any attempt to fight with the [[bourgeoisie]] on its own terms, using the same tactics and strategies as they do, will be crushed (Maoists cite that apart from the [[October Revolution]], every single revolutionary attempt that used [[conventional warfare]] was crushed by the bourgeoisie). * It cannot be predicted when the objective conditions for revolution will exist. Thus the subjective conditions—i.e. [[class consciousness]]—must be built long in advance. * Seizure of state power generally does not happen in one fell swoop. A situation of [[dual power]] through the course of protracted people's war arises when the proletarian vanguard controls sections of the country at the same time as the bourgeoisie. * The party cannot possibly hope to lead the proletariat in a seizure of power if it itself has no military experience. Thus military experience—i.e. experienced gained through actually fighting, even if on a limited scale—must be gained long in advance of a seizure of power. In addition to being a necessary development towards the dictatorship of the proletariat, dual power is invaluable in providing this military experience (along with civil knowledge, fuel for propaganda efforts, material aid for the party and the expansion and improvement of the mass line). In a joint document released in 1998, several communist parties affirmed the difference between the specific strategic line of protracted people's war and the more general (and universally applicable) people's war. Protracted people's war is identified as being a specific application of the concept of people's war to countries with a large population (or majority) of peasantry and involving encircling the cities from base areas of communist control in the countryside.{{cite web|title=General Declaration on Mao and People's War|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/new-zealand/rf-feb-99.pdf|publisher=Red Flag|accessdate=December 12, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Protracted people’s war is the only way to make revolution|url=http://www.pcr-rcp.ca/old/en/pwd/1e.php|publisher=Socialisme Maintenant!|accessdate=December 12, 2016}} The issue of applying people's war to fully industrialized first world nations is the subject of much debate. Many organizations, such as the RIM and the [[Revolutionary Communist Party of Canada]] in Canada, have put forward that much of a hypothetical people's war in the first world would take place in urban areas. === New Democracy === The theory of [[New Democracy]] holds that the national-bourgeois in semi-feudal and semi-colonial countries has a dual character in that although it is an exploitative capitalist force, it can also (though not always) side with the proletariat against colonialism, imperialism and the [[comprador]]-bourgeoisie (whose existence is due to imperialism). The role of the national-bourgeoisie as a progressive asset in the proletarian struggle to overthrow imperialism is of course never guaranteed and will eventually turn on the proletariat when the anti-imperialist situation progresses. The [[Balli Kombëtar]] in Albania in 1943 and the [[Kuomintang]] in China in the 1920s are examples of this. These national bourgeois forces temporarily allied with the proletariat of their countries (the [[Party of Labour of Albania]] and the [[Communist Party of China]], respectively) for the overthrow of imperialism but eventually turned on the proletariat once they felt their long-term existence in the new society would be threatened. Much like the [[New Economic Policy]] in Russia, New Democracy is conceived of as a necessary (but temporary) evil for the long-term development of socialism, or in this case for the construction and consolidation of socialism in the first place. Maoism holds that the national-bourgeois in the New Democratic stage must always be firmly under the command of the proletariat and they must be firmly dispensed with as soon as the national situation allows (in other words, when the contradiction between the comprador class and the people is no longer the primary contradiction of the nation, or when the bourgeois-democratic revolution is at a sufficiently advanced stage) for an outright dictatorship of the proletariat. === Cultural Revolution === Maoists draw heavily from the experiences and lessons of the [[Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution]] which sought to eradicate the bourgeois that arose within the vanguard party itself and to transform all aspects of the social superstructure. The catchphrase "class struggle continues, and is intensified, under socialism" is frequently used. Maoists hold the primacy of the relations of production over the productive forces, criticise [[Joseph Stalin]]'s line that bourgeois influence under an advanced stage of socialism is primarily due to external forces (to the almost complete exclusion of internal forces) and strongly reaffirm the [[Base and superstructure|base-superstructure]] [[Dialectics|dialectic]] (that the conscious transformation of the base on its own is not enough, but the superstructure must also be consciously transformed). === Country classification === Maoists state that there are two kinds of countries: [[Imperialism|imperialist]]-[[Capitalism|capitalist]] ones on one side and oppressed [[Semi-colony|semi-colonial]] semi-feudal countries on the other side.[https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/mao/selected-works/volume-2/mswv2_23.htm "Mao Zedong: The Chinese Revolution and the Chinese Communist Party"].[http://bannedthought.net/International/RIM/Docs/RIM-Declaration-1984-A.pdf "Declaration of the Revolutionary Internationalist Movement"]. In the oppressed countries there is a bureaucratic capitalist bourgeoisie, [[Dependency theory|submitted to imperialism]].[http://lesmaterialistes.com/english/cpmlm-declaration-59-capitalist-or-semi-feudal-semi-colonial-countries-trotskyism-or "Capitalist or semi-feudal semi-colonial countries?"]. According to this concept, in some oppressed countries the ruling class tries to be expansionist.[http://lesmaterialistes.com/english/relationship-between-semi-colonialism-and-semi-feudalism-cpmlm-bangladesh-cpmlm-france "The relationship between semi-colonialism and semi-feudalism"]. === Philosophy === {{main|Antagonistic contradiction|One Divides Into Two}} Maoists uphold [[Mao Zedong]]'s philosophical works, particularly his work on [[Dialectical materialism|dialectics]] in ''[[On Contradiction]]'' and on [[epistemology]] in ''[[On Practice]]''. == Differences from Mao Zedong Thought == The three most notable differences between Marxism–Leninism–Maoism and Mao Zedong Thought are the following:{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Nikolai|title=What is Maoism?|url=http://anti-imperialism.com/2011/08/05/what-is-maoism/|website=anti-imperialism.com|publisher=RAIM|accessdate=15 June 2014}}{{cite web|title=Marxism-Leninism-Maoism Basic Course|url=http://massalijn.nl/theory/marxism-leninism-maoism-basic-course/|website=Massalijn|publisher=Communist Party of India (Maoist)|accessdate=16 June 2014}}{{cite web|title=The five main contributions of Maoism to communist thought|url=http://www.nuovopci.it/arcspip/article7019.html|website=nuovopci.it|accessdate=16 June 2014}} # Marxism–Leninism–Maoism is considered to be a higher stage of Marxism–Leninism, much like Marxism–Leninism is considered a higher stage of [[Marxism]]. However, Mao Zedong Thought is considered to just be Marxism–Leninism applied to the particularities of the Chinese revolution. # Marxism–Leninism–Maoism is considered to be universally applicable whilst the aspects of Mao Zedong Thought are generally not. # Marxism–Leninism–Maoism completely rejects the [[Three Worlds Theory]] of Mao Zedong Thought, considering it part of the right-wards turn Mao took near the end of his life and a deviation from Marxist–Leninist theories of imperialism. == Marxism–Leninism–Maoism internationally == === Internationals === Perhaps the most notable Marxist–Leninist–Maoist international was the [[Revolutionary Internationalist Movement]] (RIM). RIM was founded in 1984 and included such organizations as the [[Shining Path|Communist Party of Peru]] (PCP), also known as "Sendero Luminoso" or "Shining Path"; and the then Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist), now known as the [[Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)]] UCPN(M). Today, the RIM appears to be defunct or near defunct. The magazine associated with the RIM, ''A World to Win'', has not published an issue since 2006, though A World to Win News Service still publishes regularly on the internet.{{cite web|url=http://www.aworldtowin.org/wordpress/|title=A World to Win News Service|date=3 April 2006|website=Aworldtowin.org|accessdate=10 November 2011}} In addition, many of the one-time RIM organizations have become increasingly critical of each other and this has resulted in many public splits. === India === {{see also|Communist Party of India (Maoist)}} The [[Communist Party of India (Maoist)]] is a [[political party]] which aims to overthrow the government of [[India]].{{cite news|title=Maoists looking at armed overthrow of state by 2050|newspaper=The Times of India|date=6 March 2010|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-03-06/india/28119932_1_maoists-indian-state-forest-land|accessdate=6 March 2010}} It was founded on 21 September 2004 through the merger of the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist–Leninist) People's War]] and the [[Maoist Communist Centre|Maoist Communist Centre of India]] (MCC). The merger was announced to the public on 14 October the same year. In the merger a provisional central committee was constituted, with the erstwhile People's War leader [[Muppala Lakshmana Rao]] (alias Ganapathi) as General Secretary. It is currently proscribed as a [[terrorist]] organization by the Indian government. === Kangleipak (Manipur) === It is claimed by the [[Kangleipak Communist Party]] (Ibungo Ngangom) that [[Manipur (princely state)|Kangleipak (Manipur)]] was annexed by the [[Dominion of India|Union of India]] under the guise of Manipur Merger Agreement of 1949. According to this group, which follows a fusion of Marxism and Maoism as its main ideological line, the merger of Manipur with the Union of India was in blatant contradiction of relevant international law as the then king of Manipur no longer had the authority to sign the agreement following the establishment of a democratically elected government. "Moreover, the then king signed the merger instrument only under duress, or more precisely, at gunpoint and so the so-called Manipur merger agreement was null and void from the very beginning", claims Ibungo Ngangom, the group's chairman. The group is currently at war with the Union of India and its express primary goal is not only to liberate Kangleipak (Manipur) from the semi-colonial yoke of India, but also to bring about a communist state in Kangleipak through the [[scientific socialism]] of [[Karl Marx]]. === Peru === The [[Shining Path|Communist Party of Peru – Shining Path]] is a [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla]] [[insurgent]] organization in [[Peru]]. It was founded in 1980 with [[Abimael Guzmán]] as its leader. The Shining Path is currently waging a [[Internal conflict in Peru|war against the Peruvian government]]. === Nepal === The [[Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)]], a national communist party with a revolutionary background, is a follower of Marxism–Leninism–Maoism, although it is believed that the party has developed its own ideology, [[Marxism–Leninism–Maoism–Prachanda Path]], which was developed taking Nepal's political, sociological and geographical constraints into consideration. The Communist Party of Nepal is another Marxist–Leninist–Maoist party in Nepal. It claims that the UCPN(M) is a revisionist organization and is continuing the People's War against the UCPN(M) government. === Philippines=== In the [[Philippines]], the [[Communist Party of the Philippines]] (CPP) and its [[New People's Army]] (NPA) has been waging a revolutionary war since 1968. Its strength peaked during the dictatorial rule of [[Ferdinand Marcos]] and was the main bulk of the opposition against the dictatorship. However, due to controversies regarding massive purges of its members in the mid-1980s and political miscalculations it suffered several splits within its ranks in 1992 and 1997 forming several separate communist parties. It maintains active guerrilla fronts throughout the Philippines until today and is still considered by the military as the main threat to national security. According to the military, the CPP also allegedly has been leading and influencing legal left-wing political organizations and engages in elections. The Marxist–Leninist Party of the Philippines (MLPP), formed by former [[Central Luzon]] Regional Committee members of the CPP after the split in 1997 maintained much of the Maoist orientation from the CPP most especially on the concept of people's war. However, it has put equal emphasis on legal political struggles along with armed revolution and it sees the proletariat as the leader of the Philippine revolution in union with the peasantry. The Rebolusyonaryong Hukbo ng Bayan (People's Revolutionary Army, RHB) is the armed wing of the MLPP and according to military intelligence sources is the most active and fastest growing insurgent force in the Philippines recently next to the CPP. Like its estranged political sibling the MLPP is said to be organizing legal organizations but does not engage in electoral processes. === United States === The [[Black Panther Party]] was a proto-Marxist–Leninist–Maoist political party in the United States, requiring all official members to read Mao's ''[[Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung|Little Red Book]]''. The [[Revolutionary Communist Party, USA|Revolutionary Communist Party]] was previously a Marxist–Leninist–Maoist political party in the United States.[http://revcom.us/a/ideology/mlm.htm Our Ideology is Marxism-Leninism-Maoism by Bob Avakian] revcom.us The RCP participated in the founding conference of the Revolutionary Internationalist Movement on 12 March 1984. The RCP signed the "Declaration of the Revolutionary Internationalist Movement"[https://archive.org/download/DeclarationOfTheRevolutionaryInternationalistMovement_292/DeclarationOfTheRevolutionaryInternationalistMovement_292.pdf "Declaration of the Revolutionary Internationalist Movement"]. and supported the RIM's declaration "Long Live Marxism–Leninism–Maoism!" on 26 December 1993 which recognized "Marxism–Leninism–Maoism as the new, third and higher stage of Marxism". However, today the RCP uses the term "New Synthesis" to describe its ideology and has moved away from Marxism–Leninism–Maoism, although they still call themselves Maoists.[http://revcom.us/a/129/New_Synthesis_Speech-en.html "What is Bob Avakian's New Synthesis?"]. The RCP is considered to be a [[Revisionism (Marxism)|revisionist]] organization by several Maoist groups, such as the [[Communist Party of India (Maoist)]],[http://www.bannedthought.net/India/CPI-ML-Naxalbari/Naxalbari-Magazine/Naxalbari-04.pdf "Against Avakianism"]. the [[Revolutionary Communist Party of Canada]][http://www.pcr-rcp.ca/en/archives/1849 "Proletarians of all countries, unite! Long live the 50th anniversary of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution! Long live the Proletarian World Revolution! Long live Maoism!"]. and several smaller Maoist formations in the United States. ==See also== * [[Socialism with Chinese characteristics]] * [[Xi Jinping Thought]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140411203548/http://www.aworldtowin.org/back_issues/1995-20/ll_mlm_20_eng.htm Revolutionary Internationalist Movement: Long Live Marxism-Leninism-Maoism!] * [http://lesmaterialistes.com/english/communist-party-peru-fundamental-documents Communist Party of Peru: On Marxism-Leninism-Maoism] * [http://massalijn.nl/theory/marxism-leninism-maoism-basic-course/ Communist Party of India (Maoist): Marxism-Leninism-Maoism Basic Course] {{Maoism}} {{Communism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marxism-Leninism-Maoism}} [[Category:Marxist schools of thought]] [[Category:Leninism]] [[Category:Maoism]] [[Category:Anti-revisionism]] [[Category:Communism]] [[Category:Eponymous political ideologies]] [[Category:Types of socialism]]

The '''Menus-Plaisirs du Roi''' ({{IPA-fr|məny pleziʁ dy ʁwa}}) was, in the organisation of the [[France|French]] royal household under the [[Ancien Régime]], the department of the [[Maison du Roi]] responsible for the "lesser pleasures of the King", which meant in practice that it was in charge of all the preparations for ceremonies, events and festivities, down to the last detail of design and order.
==The controller of the Menus-Plaisirs== At the king's ''[[Levée (ceremony)#Louis XIV's lever|lever]]'', the ''premier gentilhomme de la chambre'' (First [[Gentleman of the Bedchamber]]), controller of the Menus-Plaisirs, was invariably in attendance, to hear directly from the king what plans were to be set in motion; by long-standing convention, he was a duke; though he was not a professional, it was up to him to determine the appropriate designs. The duke in charge of the Menus et Plaisirs du Roy was an important court official, quite separate from the Surintendant des [[Bâtiments du Roi]], who was an architect or aristocrat in charge of all building operations undertaken by the Crown. The dukes in charge might leave the design process entirely to the professional ''intendant'' in charge, whose right-hand man was the ''dessinateur du cabinet et de la chambre du Roy''; so did two dukes with military careers, [[Louis François Armand du Plessis, duc de Richelieu|Louis-François-Armand du Plessis, duc de Richelieu]] (1696-1788), appointed ''premier gentilhomme'' in 1744<ref>Eriksen 1974</ref> and [[Emmanuel-Félicité, duc de Durfort-Duras]] (1715–89), made ''premier gentilhomme'' (and ''[[pair de France]]'') in 1757.<ref>Eriksen 1974 notes that though the catafalque for the king and queen of Spain, at the funeral in Notre-Dame, 15 January 1760, marked the first appearance in court circles of neoclassical design, it is not clear whether the duc de Durfort de Duras played any role in its design.</ref> But [[Louis-Marie-Augustin, duc d'Aumont]] (1709–82), appointed ''premier gentilhomme de la chambre'' in 1723, a position he held until the king's death in 1774, was a noted connoisseur of objets d'art and the arts of life, though not, apparently, of paintings.<ref>At the sale of his collection after his death, in 1782, purchases were made on behalf of Marie-Antoinette.</ref> The duc d'Aumont appointed the renowned gilt-bronze maker [[Pierre Gouthière]] ''doreur ordinaire'' of the Menus-Plaisirs in 1767 and appointed the architect Bellanger to the Menus-Plaisirs in the same year.<ref>Eriksen 1974:148-49</ref> For most of the reign of Louis XVI, the ''intendant'' of the Menus-Plaisirs du Roi was [[Papillon de la Ferté]], whose journal (published in 1887) throws a great deal of light on the organization of court ceremony.<ref>Alain-Charles Gruber, ''Les Grandes Fêtes et leurs Décors à l'Époque de Louis XVI'' (Geneva: Droz) 1972.</ref>
==Design== Many designers were required at the Menus-Plaisirs. From the sixteenth century on, a main responsibility of court architects in Europe was the occasional design of lavish ephemeral settings for processional entries, for [[masque]]s and [[ballet]]s, for the structures that supported fireworks and illuminations on nights of grand fêtes for dynastic marriages and births, or to design the [[catafalque]] for a state funeral. Architects like [[Leonardo da Vinci|Leonardo]], [[Giulio Romano]] and [[Inigo Jones]] were engaged in projects that were of great moment in expressing the prestige of the court, but which have left little behind, except designs and some commemorative engravings, produced under the supervision of the Cabinet du Roi.<ref>In addition, extensive descriptions were published after each notable event in the ''Mercure de France''.</ref> The architect [[Charles-Nicolas Cochin]] worked for several years for the Menus-Plaisirs du Roi, 1735–51, making detailed renderings for the engravers of architectural designs by the [[Slodtz|Slodtz brothers]].<ref>Carter E. Foster, "Charles-Nicolas Cochin and Festival Design for the Menus-Plaisirs" ''Master Drawings'' '''39'''.3 (Autumn 2001), pp. 260-278; p. 276 note 3 gives a bibliography concerning Cochin's work for the Menus-Plaisirs.</ref> and [[François-Joseph Bélanger]] began his career in 1767 working at the Menus-Plaisirs, both designing ephemeral decorations for court entertainments.
In the later reign of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]], the architect in charge of the Bâtiments was [[Jules Hardouin-Mansart]], but the wholly independent artistic force at the menus-plaisirs until his death in 1711 was [[Jean Bérain the Elder|Jean Bérain]], whose brevet in 1674 covered his responsibilities "for all sorts of designs, perspectives, figures and costumes that it would be required to make for plays, ballets, chases at the ring, [[carousel]]s..."<ref>"''pour toutes sortes de desseins, perspectives, Figures et habits qu'il conviendrait Faire pour les Comedies, Balets<!--Balets in original--> Courses de bagues et Carousels..."'' (Fiske Kimball, ''The Creation of the Rococo'' [Philadelphia] 1943, p. 40.)</ref> The purview of the Menus-Plaisirs did not normally extend to furniture, but among its expenses in 1692 were "the Furniture and the silversmiths' work for the apartments of the King"<ref>"les Meubles et l'argenterie pour les appartements du Roi" (Kimball 1943:40).</ref>
==Personnel== Within the Menus-Plaisirs, a hierarchical structure prevailed, with an ''Intendant''<ref>Until 1762 there was also a ''Contrôleur''; the post of ''Intendant'' (held by Papillon de la Ferté at the time) was exchanged for a ''Commissaire'' in 1780. (Boysse 1887:5</ref> supervising the whole and a ''Dessinateur de la Chambre et du Cabinet du Roi'' in charge of the orderly production of designs. The ''Cabinet du Roi''—in the seventeenth-century sense of ''cabinet'' as collection of works of art and curiosities—was organized by [[Jean-Baptiste Colbert|Colbert]], who gave formal structure to all the official arts under Louis XIV. The ''Cabinet du Roi'' provided the commemorative engravings, which are often our only record, and sold them.<ref>The ''Cabinet du Roi'' as a publishing venture was examined by C. Ferraton, "Les fêtes de Louis XIV et le cabinet de planches gravées fondé par Colbert" ''Bulletin des Musées de France'' '''12.5''' (September–October 1947), pp 26-28.</ref> The functions of design and commemoration overlapped, needless to say. The position was extremely influential: both [[Jean Bérain the Elder|Jean Bérain]] and [[Jean Bérain the Younger|his son]], and later [[Juste-Aurèle Meissonnier]], the genius of the extreme [[rococo]], followed by the [[Slodtz]] brothers, one after another, 1750-64. The appointment of the neo-classical architect-designer [[Michel-Ange Challe]] in 1764 marked a turning point: through his designs for the Menus-Plaisirs, [[neoclassicism]] was introduced at the French court.<ref>Gruber 1972.</ref>
==Expenses== In addition to these extraordinary expenses, which interest the historian of taste, the journal of the last ''Intendant'' of the Menus-Plaisirs, [[Denis-Pierre-Jean Papillon de la Ferté]] (1727-1794) describes as well the ordinary expenses, for the Menus-Plaisirs dispensed the salaries of the ''Premiers Gentilshommes de la Chambre'', the ''Grand Maître de la Garde-Robe'', the king's doctor, the ''médecin de la Chambre'', the personnel of the Menus-Plaisirs and the king's musicians. Ordinary expenses entailed the constant renewal of the King's wardrobe and that of the Dauphin, religious ceremonies of all kinds, the king's carriages, small royal gifts like snuffboxes, tents and pavilions for outdoor events.
==Limits== The Menus-Plaisirs were not in charge of the essential furniture of the royal palaces, which were the province of the [[Garde-Meuble de la Couronne]]. An exception is instructive: the design of the jewel cabinet made as a wedding present for the wedding of the Dauphin Louis to [[Marie-Antoinette]] was considered part of the design of the festivities as a whole; thus in the Menus-Plaisirs, the design was entrusted by the duc d'Aumont to [[Belanger]] in 1769, well in advance of the wedding. It was delivered on 1 May 1770.<ref>Eriksen 1974:plate 448.</ref>
=={{Anchor|Salle des Menus-Plaisirs (rue Bergère)}}Music division on the rue Bergère== <!--The above section anchor is the target of the redirect "Salle des Menus-Plaisirs (rue Bergère)". Please do not remove it until the redirect no longer links to it.--> {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1=Plan of the Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs (Rue Bergère) - Gourret 1985 p84.jpg |image2=Long section of the Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs (Rue Bergère) - Gourret 1985 p83.jpg |footer=Plan and long section of the Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs on the rue Bergère ({{Circa|1780}}) }} The music required for these entertainments was also a concern of the Menus-Plaisirs du Roi. Beginning in 1762 the music section was established on a large site extending north from the rue Bergère and west of the rue du Faubourg Poissonnière. The facilities included what had previously been the theatre of the [[Opéra-Comique]] at the [[Saint-Laurent Fair]].<ref>Wild 1989, p. 258; Gourret 1985, pp. 81–84</ref> The site was soon expanded until it reached the rue Richer on the north.
In 1784 [[Denis-Pierre-Jean Papillon de la Ferté|Papillon de la Ferté]] organized the École Royale de Musique, which was housed in buildings on this site on the rue Bergère, and in 1793 the Institut National de Musique, responsible for training instrumentalists of the [[National Guard (France)|National Guard]] [[Marching band|bands]], was also located here. The two institutions were merged into the [[Conservatoire de Musique]] in August 1795. A new [[Salle des Concerts du Conservatoire|Conservatory Concert Hall]] was added in 1811. Under the [[French Second Empire]] a different theatre with the name [[Théâtre des Menus-Plaisirs]] was constructed at 14 Boulevard de Strasbourg in Paris.<ref>Wild 1989, pp. 258–262.</ref><ref>Anne Bongrain and Yves Gérard, ''Le Conservatoire de Paris, des Menus-Plaisirs à la Cité de la musique, 1795-1995'' (Paris:Buchet-Chastel) 1999.</ref>
==Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs du Roi in Versailles== [[File:Estatesgeneral.jpg|thumb|left|The meeting of the Estates General, in the Salle des États, 5 May 1789]]
Under Louis XV a structure was erected in the town of [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]] to house the multiple activities of the Menus-Plaisirs. It still stands, at 22, avenue de Paris, now rendered famous as the site of the [[Estates-General of 1789]], at which the opening moves of the [[French Revolution]] were played out. A provisionally fitted-out space was arranged in the building to seat the Assembly of Notables in 1787, and again in 1788. Then, to accommodate the press of representatives of the three estates, in the Estate-General, a grander but still temporary Salle des États designed by [[Pierre-Adrien Pâris]] was set up in one of the two courtyards of the Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs. The old Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs is now the home of the [[Centre de Musique Baroque de Versailles]].
==Menus-Plaisirs at the court of Russia== In Moscow, near the Kremlin's walls, between the Komendantskaïa Tower and the Troïtskaïa Tower, stands the '''Palais des Menus Plaisirs''' (Потёшный Дворец or Потёшный Двор), built in 1652 for the father-in-law of [[Tsar Alexis]], the boyar [[Ilya Miloslavsky]], who lived in it for sixteen years. After his death, the structure was enlarged and converted into a site for spectacles and concerts, taking its new name, and served to house members of the imperial family: here the future [[Peter the Great]] received his elementary education.<ref>[[:fr:Palais des Menus Plaisirs|(French Wikipedia)"Palais des Menus Plaisirs"]]</ref>

Valdemara 10/12
[[Riga]], [[Latvia]] |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = [[Raimonds Bergmanis]] |minister1_pfo = Minister |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|www.mod.gov.lv}} |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Defence''' of the [[Republic of Latvia]] ({{lang-lv|Latvijas Republikas Aizsardzības ministrija}}) is the Latvian [[government ministry]] in charge of the formation and implementation of [[national security]] and defence policy, and for the overall management and control of related subordinate agencies. The ministry is headed by the politically appointed '''Minister of Defence'''. ==Core tasks== * Strategic analysis, research and development (R&D) * The development of long-term policy including future strategic concepts and doctrines * Perspective and structural planning * Planning, budgeting and implementation in the medium and short term * Overall management of agencies’ activities during the budget year * Operational policy, planning and management at a strategic level * Exercise policy, planning and management at a strategic level * Emergency planning, policy and management at a strategic level * Crisis management * Development and implementation of security policy, both nationally and internationally * Development of defence cooperation with allied- and partner countries * Strategic personnel management * Information, communication and press relations * Strategic leadership and management in the field of ICT * Organisational development * Preventive security at a strategic level * Legal questions * Controller / Internal audit * Internal administration ==See also== *[[List of Ministers of Defence of Latvia]] ==External links== *[http://www.mod.gov.lv/?lang=en Official website] [[Category:Defence ministries|Latvia]] [[Category:Government of Latvia]] [[Category:Military of Latvia]] {{Latvia-poli-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Mosaica Education, Inc. | logo = [[File:Mosaica-Education.gif|options|caption]] | caption = Mosaica's mission is to empower students to learn and achieve--every child, every day. | type = [[Charter management organization]] | traded_as = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1997 | founder = Dr. Dawn Eidelman and Gene Eidelman | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = Atlanta, GA | location_country = United States | location = | locations = | area_served = Global (USA, UK, India, Mexico, etc) | key_people = Gene Eidelman, Mike Connelly, Dr. Dawn Eidelman | industry = Education | products = Curriculum, School Model, Education Services | services = School Management, Education Consulting, Online Schooling, Education Professional Development, Education Turn Arounds, Curriculum | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,800 | parent = [[Pansophic Learning]] (as of 2015) | divisions = Mosaica Online, Mosaica Turnaround Partners, Mosaica International Schools, Mosaica Education UK, Paragon | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://mosaicaeducation.com/}} | footnotes = }} '''Mosaica Education, Inc.''' is an education management organization that operates preschool, elementary, middle and high school programs in the United States, United Kingdom and India in addition to other countries through Mosaica Online. Mosaica Education was founded in 1997. It acquired Advantage Schools, Inc., in 2001. Mosaica Education's primary focus is developing charter school programs in the United States that use its proprietary Paragon curriculum. Mosaica Education is co-headquartered in New York City and Atlanta, Georgia. The organization employs more than 1,800 people, primarily at the school-site level, and operates 104 programs for 25,000 students worldwide as of November 2013.<ref name=hoovers>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company/Mosaica_Education_Inc/rfhcfyi-1.html |title=Mosaica Education, Inc. | Company Profile from Hoover’s |publisher=Hoovers.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref><ref name=palmbeachpost>{{cite web|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/local-education/west-palm-school-would-be-charter-firms-first-in-f/nb4k3/|title=West Palm school would be charter firm’s first in Florida|author=Eliot Kleinberg|publisher=The Palm Beach Post|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> Michael J. Connelly is Mosaica's [[chief executive officer]].<ref name=hoovers/><ref name=palmbeachpost/>
The company's educational assets were taken over by [[Pansophic Learning]] in 2015. No Mosaica-branded schools remain.
==History==
===Early history=== Mosaica was co-founded in 1997 by Dr. Dawn Eidelman and Gene Eidelman. The Eidelmans had previously founded Prodigy Child Development Centers and Prodigy Consulting, an organization that operated child development and care centers in the Atlanta, Georgia area and for corporations across the United States including [[General Motors]], [[IBM]] and [[Xerox]].<ref name=mcall>{{cite web|url=http://articles.mcall.com/2000-03-12/news/3289084_1_mosaica-education-school-boards-public-schools|title=Charter Schools Fight To Exist, But Do They Work?|publisher=The Morning Call|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=CEO Interview CHILDREN'S DISCOVERY CENTERS OF AMERICA INC. (CDCR)|date=3 April 1995|publisher=The Wall Street Transcript}}</ref> Dr. Dawn Eidelman also formerly served as a professor at the [[University of Texas at Arlington]].<ref name=mcall/> In September 1997, Mosaica opened its first charter school.<ref name=bizjournals>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/stories/2001/07/02/daily11.html|title=Mosaica Education to acquire struggling Advantage Schools|publisher=Boston Business Journal|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> Lepercq Capital Management purchased a stake of the company in 1998.<ref name=greyhouse>{{cite web|title=A Look at For-Profit EMOs Charter School Movement: History, Politics, Policies, Economics and Effectiveness|author=Danny Weil|edition=2|publisher=Grey House Publishing|year=2009|pages=319–334}}</ref> Along with the investment, Michael Connelly, a former president of Lepercq, became Mosaica's chief executive officer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1998-10-13/news/25759747_1_mosaica-education-mosaica-academy-charter-school-gene-eidelman|title=Mosaica Company Gains Investor The Firm Operates A Bensalem Charter School. A New Top Manager Will Step In As Well.|author=Lisa Shafer|publisher=Philly.com|date=October 13, 1998|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> The company received further funding from Murphy and Partners in 1999.<ref name=greyhouse/>
===2000s=== In 2001, Mosaica acquired Advantage Schools, a [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]]-based education management organization.<ref name=bizjournals/> The Qatari government contracted Mosaica to convert schools in Qatar to an American-style educational curriculum in 2003.<ref name=incmagazine>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/20060701/handson-global.html|title=A Whole New World|publisher=Inc.|accessdate=14 April 2014}}</ref> The contract was renewed in 2006.<ref name=incmagazine/> By 2005, Mosaica was the fastest growing urban business in the country, according to ''Inc. Magazine''.<ref name=newsday>{{cite web|title=Mosaica Education named country's fastest growing urban business|author=Marshall, Randi F.|publisher=Newsday|date=27 April 2005}}</ref> The company operated 51 charter schools at the time.<ref name=newsday/>
In 2004 and 2007, Mosaica was recognized as one of the Outstanding Charters Schools in America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050422005499/en/Mosaica-Education-Ranked-Number-City-100-York-Based#.U1b_s-ZdW2A|title=Mosaica Education, Inc. Ranked Number One on `Inner City 100'; New York-Based Mosaica Education is Fastest-Growing Urban Company in America|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gse-harvard-csm.symplicity.com/events/students.php?mode=profile&eid=a6678919d38f1613b8f1dbaca2f3be84&regid=27770584a7e69c84585de45dbde15392&pmode=overview&cf=prek12expo2014&s=&ss=|title=The Met- A Big Picture Learning School|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> Mosaica was one of two education organizations to appear on the 2004 "Inc 5000" list.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/inc5000/list/2004/100/city/ | title = 2004 Inc 5000 | publisher = Inc. | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2006, Mosaica Education was selected by the government of Abu Dhabi as one of four private education firms to consult on 30 government schools in the Abu Dhabi Education Council (ADEC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.gulfnews.com/private-educational-firms-to-manage-30-public-schools-1.233325|title=Private educational firms to manage 30 public schools|author=Mohammad Shamseddine|date=April 17, 2006|publisher=GulfNews|accessdate=August 3, 2014}}</ref> The Public-Private Partnership (PPP) program was considered successful in 2010 when ADEC reported that "there has been a considerable rise in student and teacher attendance and grades specifically in English, Math, and Arabic language skills."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ameinfo.com/blog/company-news/a/adec/adec-meets-with-ppp-to-assess-progress-in-abu-dhabi-schools/|title=ADEC meets with PPP to assess progress in Abu Dhabi schools|date=March 8, 2010|publisher=AME|accessdate=August 3, 2014}}</ref>
In 2006, Mosaica was paid $773,000 for the first year of a five-year management contract for the management of Lafayette Academy Charter School in [[New Orleans|New Orleans, Louisiana]].<ref name=nola>{{cite web|url=http://blog.nola.com/times-picayune/2007/09/charter_school_wins_lawsuit_ag.html|title=Charter school wins lawsuit against management company|author=Darran Simon|publisher=''The Times-Picayune''|accessdate=14 April 2014}}</ref> The organization was fired in 2007 by the school's governing board, which alleged that Mosaica failed to align its curriculum to Louisiana state standards, provide after-school programs for students that were below grade level, and organize transportation to and from the school.<ref name=nola/> The dispute between Mosaica and Lafayette Academy went into arbitration.<ref name=nola/> In September 2007, the arbitrator ruled Lafayette Academy would pay Mosaica $100,000 for early termination of the contract and Mosaica would return $350,000 in fees to the school.<ref name=nola/>
In 2009, Mosaica fired one school administrator and two teachers at Howard Road Academy, a charter school managed by the organization.<ref name=washingtonpost>{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/class-struggle/2009/08/cheating_on_dc-cas_costs_chart.html|title=Cheating on DC-CAS Costs Charter School|author=Jay Mathews|authorlink=Jay Mathews|publisher=''The Washington Post''|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> The administrator had leaked a copy of the DC-CAS standardized test to two teachers, who then distributed copies of the test to their students prior to the exam day.<ref name=washingtonpost/>
===2010s=== In 2010, the MAPSA (Michigan Association of Public School Academies) recognized Bingham Arts with the Charter School of Excellence Award for the state of Michigan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mosaicaeducation.com/2010/11/04/mpsa-recognizes-bingham-arts-charter-school-of-excellence-award/|title=MAPSA Recognizes Bingham Arts with the Charter School of Excellence Award|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.charterschools.org/school-services/2013-conference/2009-awards | title = 2013 Conference Awards | publisher = Michigan Association of Public School Academies | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref> The Columbus Preparatory Academy was recognized as a 'School of Excellence with Distinction' by the Ohio Department of Education in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Columbus Preparatory Academy (CPA) – K-8 School of Excellence with Distinction |url=http://www.buckeyecharterboards.org/Columbus%20Preparatory%20Academy%20School%20of%20Excelence%20with%20Distinction%20_2_.pdf|accessdate=14 September 2011|newspaper=|date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/8/prweb8731474.htm | title = Columbus Preparatory Academy Celebrates 'Excellent with Distinction' | publisher = PR Web | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, a charter school managed by Mosaica Education received the Illinois State Board of Education's "Academic Improvement Award."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.isbe.state.il.us/news/2012/feb27.htm | title = State Board Celebrates Academic Improvement at Harvard Elementary in Chicago Public Schools | publisher = Illinois State Board of Education | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref> A charter school managed by Mosaica Education received the 2012 Colorado "Governors' Distinguished Improvement Award" for exceeding academic expectations.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cde.state.co.us/cdeawards/govdistinguishedschools2012 | title = 2012 Colorado Governor's Distinguished Improvement Awards | publisher = Colorado Department of Education | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
In April 2012, the ''Winston-Salem Journal'' reported that the STEAM Academy of [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] had faced declining revenue and poor academic performance for multiple years.<ref name=winston>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/local/article_5439f5c7-e494-51d3-aa0e-426fee0d97dd.html|title=Downtown charter school fighting for survival|author=Travis Fain|publisher=''Winston-Salem Journal''|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> Mosaica took over management of the charter school in late 2011.<ref name=winston/> The STEAM Academy's board of directors hired Susan Willis to serve as the school's principal in December of that year.<ref name=winston/> Willis had been fired in 2009 from Fleming High School in [[Roanoke, Virginia]] for allegedly manipulating student schedules to influence the school's standardized testing scores.<ref name=winston/> Mosaica was aware of Willis' firing but felt that Willis was "cleared of any wrongdoing" after the company spoke to a former Roanoke school superintendent and consulted a dissenting opinion from the Virginia state investigation into Willis' conduct.<ref name=winston/>
Also in 2012, Mosaica was contracted to manage a charter district in Muskegon Heights, Michigan by Donald Weatherspoon, the emergency manager of the failing district.<ref name=educationweek>{{cite web|url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2013/05/01/30charters_ep.h32.html|title=For-Profit Experiment Plays Out in Two Mich. Districts|author=Katie Ash|publisher=Education Week|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> Prior to contracting with Mosaica, Weatherspoon had fired the entire staff of the school district and reconstituted it as a charter district.<ref name=educationweek/> Mosaica had "three months to hire and train staff members, including those rehired from the old district, bring neglected facilities up to code, and persuade parents to keep their children enrolled."<ref name=educationweek/> The school's first principal quit within the first month of that school year and, within three months, a quarter of the teachers hired by Mosaica in the summer had left the district.<ref name=educationweek/> According to [[Education Week]], "the largest single proportion [of teachers who left the district]—28 percent—cited the charter district's lack of participation in Michigan's public school employee retirement plan as the reason [for leaving]."<ref name=educationweek/>
In 2013, a charter school managed by Mosaica Education is recognized by the Ohio Department of Education as a "High Progress School of Honor."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://education.ohio.gov/Topics/School-Improvement/Awards-and-Recognition/Schools-of-Honor | title = Schools of Honor | publisher = Ohio Department of Education | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref> As of 2013, Atlanta Preparatory Academy, a charter school managed by Mosaica, ranked in the bottom 20% of schools in Georgia based on standardized testing scores.<ref name=turnaround>{{cite web|url=http://www.educationturnaround.com |title=Mosaica Turnaround Partners |publisher=Educationturnaround.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Atlanta Public Schools recommended that the Georgia Board of Education not renew the school's charter due to low standardized test scores.<ref name=turnaround/> The public school district was also concerned that the charter school's board lacked sufficient independence because it owed $801,384 to Mosaica.<ref name=turnaround/>
In 2014, Tatonka Capital sued Mosaica, claiming default on loans.<ref name="tt140220">{{cite news|last1=MORGAN-BESECKER|first1=TERRIE|title=Firm sues Fell Charter School for $2.1 million|url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/firm-sues-fell-charter-school-for-2-1-million-1.1637744|accessdate=26 January 2018|publisher=Times-Tribune|date=February 20, 2014}}</ref> Mosaica went into court-ordered receivership in September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=TATONKA CAPITAL CORPORATION v. MOSAICA EDUCATION, INC.|url=https://www.leagle.com/decision/infdco20141218950|publisher=United States District Court, D. Colorado.|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=October 31, 2014}}</ref> In 2015, Tatonka and [[Pansophic Learning]] acquired the company's assets out of bankruptcy.<ref name="bb180126">{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Mosaica Education, Inc.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=536734|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref>
==Divisions== Mosaica Education is the parent organization that manages US-based charter schools and provides education consulting services. Additionally, there are five divisions within the organization:
'''Mosaica Online'''
Mosaica Online (formerly known as Mercury Online Education) is a virtual education program available to students domestically and internationally. Students attend classes and interact with peers and teachers through an online learning management system. In addition to offering virtual schools, Mosaica Online also partners with schools looking to offer online courses on an à la carte basis.
'''Mosaica Turnaround Partners''' Mosaica Turnaround Partners is a consultant for schools and school districts facing a wide range of educational challenges. Mosaica Turnaround Partners assist school administrators with rescuing their academic programs from failure. Mosaica Turnaround Partners use professional development, research and tracking to improve the academic achievement of schools focusing on predominantly at risk student populations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mosaicaeducation.com/paragon |title=Charter Schools Curriculum | Mosaica Education Curriculum |publisher=Mosaicaeducation.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
'''Mosaica International Schools''' Mosaica International Schools (formerly known as Mosaica American Schools) is Mosaica Education's division that operates private international schools located outside of the United States. Mosaica currently operates one school in Hyderabad, India, although a school in Guragon had been planned in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mosaicaeducation.com/paragon/our-pillars/ |title=Charter School Model & Benefits | Mosiaca Education Pillars |publisher=Mosaicaeducation.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
'''Mosaica Education UK''' Mosaica Education UK provides school management, professional development and education consulting services to schools and governments within the United Kingdom. At present Mosaica Education UK operates four academies in England under the Aurora Academies Trust.<ref name=columbia>{{cite web|url=http://columbia.news21.com/2009/indexee0c.html?p=1364 |title=A for-profit charter school company loses multiple clients. | columbia.news21.com | The Charter Explosion | Carnegie-Knight Initiative for Future of Journalism Education |publisher=columbia.news21.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
'''Paragon''' Paragon is an accelerated learning program that replaces traditional social studies, history, geography and civics curriculum at the primary and secondary school levels.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.coloradoan.com/story/opinion/contributors/2014/08/06/soapbox-count-charter-good-school-option/13644917/ | title = Soapbox: Don't count out charter as good school option | work = Coloradoan | accessdate = 10 September 2014}}</ref> Paragon also integrates the Visual and Performing Arts. Paragon supports scholarship in all subject areas by emphasizing pedagogies such as inquiry-based learning. Paragon was developed by Dr. Dawn Eidelman and is one of the eight pillars in Mosaica's accredited school model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michiganradio.org/post/many-muskegon-heights-students-dig-charter-company-s-curriculum-it-s-fun |title=Many Muskegon Heights students dig the charter company’s curriculum: "It’s fun." |publisher=Michigan Radio |date=2013-01-04 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref><ref name = theobserver>{{cite web|author=Jamie Doward |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2013/may/18/academy-pays-for-us-curriculum |title=Sussex academy pays £100,000 to use 'patented' US school curriculum | Education | The Observer |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref>
==Paragon== One distinction of Mosaica Education is the use of its proprietary Paragon curriculum instead of traditional social studies in nearly all of its schools.<ref name=hoovers/><ref name="Is Profit Dead?">{{cite news|last=McCloskey|first=Sharon|title=Is Profit Dead?|url=http://columbia.news21.com/2009/index313f.html?p=752|accessdate=19 August 2011|newspaper=News21|date=July 30, 2009}}</ref> Paragon was designed by Mosaica's co-founder Dr. Dawn Eidelman.
In a Michigan Radio article, some Mosaica students described the program as fun.<ref name=educationweek/> The same article quotes a former teacher as saying that Paragon has a one-size-fits-all approach that incorporated a "strict" teaching schedule making it hard for students to gain an understanding of the material or develop teacher / student relationships.<ref name=educationweek/>
An article published in May 2013 in ''[[The Observer]]'' commented that the Paragon curriculum appeared to be at odds with [[Secretary of State for Education|British Secretary of State for Education]] [[Michael Gove|Michael Gove's]] views of how history should be taught in the [British] curriculum. Gove's comment pertained to secondary students.<ref name = theobserver/> The article also referred to a 2003 study conducted by the [[American Federation of Teachers]] union, which suggested that self-evaluation measures taken by the school to demonstrate Paragon effectiveness had inflated student scores, a claim denied by the organization.
In February 2014, the Manav Rachna International School - Charmwood, which uses Paragon curriculum, received the Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India (ASSOCHAM) National Education Excellence Award for the "Best K-12 School in Teaching and Learning Practices."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://mriscwfaridabad.mris.edu.in/mris-charmwood-wins-assocham-national-education-excellence-award-2014/ | title = MRIS, Charmwood Wins ASSOCHAM National Education Excellence Award – 2014 | accessdate = 10 September 2014 }}</ref>
In May 2014, the UK Office of Standards in Education (Ofsted) changed its rating of King Offa Primary Academy from "Special Measures" to "Good" and praised its use of Paragon curriculum.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bexhillobserver.net/news/local/good-ofsted-news-for-bexhill-primary-school-1-5050860 | title = Good Ofsted news for Bexhill primary school | accessdate = 10 September 2014 }}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== In 2000, co-founder Dr. Dawn Eidelman received the Ten Outstanding Young Americans (TOYA) Award.<ref name=outstanding>{{cite web|url=http://www.jayceemember.com/toya/profile_Honoree.asp?hid=186 |title=Ten Outstanding Young Americans - The United States Junior Chamber - Honoree Profile |publisher=Jayceemember.com |date=2013-06-08 |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> In 2003, the United States Department of Education recognized Mosaica Education as an "Education Innovator".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/news/newsletters/innovator/2003/0908.html |title=Archived: The Education Innovator-September 8, 2003 |publisher=.ed.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref> Mosaica was recognized on the Inner-City 100 list for 4 consecutive years (2004–2007), including the #1 spot in 2005.<ref name="autogeneratedicic">{{cite web|url=http://www.icic.org/resources-for-inner-city-ceos/inner-city-100-programs |title=Inner City 100 Program |publisher=ICIC |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.icic.org/markets-and-opportunities/fast-growing-companies | title = THE INNER CITY'S FASTEST-GROWING COMPANIES | publisher = ICIC | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/20050601/inner100-1-10.html | title = 100 Street-Smart Companies | publisher = Inc. | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/20060601/ic100-1-10.html | title = The Inner City 100 Profiles: 1-10 | publisher = Inc. | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/20070601/features-inner-city-100-71-80.html | title = The 2007 Inner City 100 Profiles: 71-80 | publisher = Inc. | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
Mosaica appeared on the 2005, 2007, 2009, and 2010 "Inc. 5000" list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/mosaica-education|title=Mosaica Education|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> In 2011, it was recognized by ''Inc. Magazine'' as one of the "Top Education Companies".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/inc5000/list/2011/industry/education/ | title = The 2011 Inc. 5000 | publisher = Inc. | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2007, Mosaica Education received the Inner City Impact Award (ICIC).<ref name="autogeneratedicic"/> Mosaica co-founders Gene and Dr. Dawn Eidelman were recognized in 2009 as Education Entrepreneurs of the Year.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.educationindustry.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=85:member-news-1&catid=26:jan-2012-newsletter | title = Mosaica Education Recognized for its Global Growth | publisher = Education Industry Association | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
Mosaica was recognized on AllWorld Network's Arabia FastGrowth 500 list in 2011 and 2012. Michael Connelly received the AllWorld Entrepreneur of the Year in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.allworldlive.com/arabia-500/winners/2011 | title = Arabia 500 | publisher = AllWorld Network | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref> In 2013, the USDLA awarded Dr. Dawn D. Eidelman for "Outstanding Leadership by an Individual in the Field of Distance Learning" Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2013/4/prweb10678455.htm|title=USDLA 2013 International Awards Presented for Excellence in Distance Learning for Individuals, Organizations and Companies Honoring their Outstanding Achievements|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> Mosaica received the Top Homeschooling Curriculum Award in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.homeschool.com/articles/Curriculum-Awards-2013/ | title = Top Homeschooling Curriculum & Products for 2013! | publisher = Homeschool.com | accessdate = 29 March 2015}}</ref>
